For so he fynde goddis fusou ther̉er/re
Of the remenᵃnt nediþ not to enqr̉er/re
What shuld I more sey but þˢ Milner̉er/re
He nold for noman his wurdꝭes forber̉er/re
But told his cherlis tale in þis maner̉er/re
Me forthink þat I shal reherce it her̉er/re
Wherfor̉er/re eủer/rey gentil wight I prey
Demeþ not for goddis loue þat I sey
Of euel intent but þat I must rehers
Þeir̉er/re talis / albe thei bett̉er/re or wers
Or ellis falsen sum of my matier̉er/re
And þ̉er/refore whoso list it not to her̉er/re
Turne oủer/re the leef and seche anoþ̉er/re tale
For ye shul finde ynow gret ⁊and smale
Of historial þing þᵗat touchiþ gentilnes
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blame not me þough þᵗat ye chese ys
Þe Milner̉er/re is A cherl ye know wel þis
So was the Reve eke and othir mo
And harlotry thei tolden bothe two
Aviseth you and putte me out of blame
And eke men shuld not make ernest of game
The Milners tale
Whilom þ̉er/re was duelling in Oxenford
A riche gnoffe þᵗat gestis held to bord
And of his craft he was a Carpinter
Wᵗith him ther was wonnyng A Scoler
Had lerned Art but alle his fantasie
Was turned to lerne Astrologie
And couth a certeyne of conclusioıı̄uns
To demen by Interrogacioıı̄uns
If þᵗat men askid him in c̉er/reten houres
Whan þᵗat men shuld haue drouȝt or shourꝭes
Or if þat men askid him what shuld befal
Of eueri þing I mai not reken all
This clerc was clepid hend Nicolas
Of dern loue he couth and of solas
And þ̉er/reto he was slie and right pⁱriuee
And like a mayden eke vnto see
A chambir had he in that hostery
Alone withouten any cumpany
Ful fetisly dight with herbis sote
And he himselue as swete as is þᵉ rote
Of licoris or of any Setwale
His Almagist and bokis gret ⁊and smale
His Astrelabre longing to his Art
His Augrym stones lying feir apart
On shelues couchid at his beddis hede
His presse coủer/reed wᵗith A falding rede
And al aboue þ̉er/re lay A gay Sautry
On which he made on nightꝭes melody
So swetly that al þe chambre rong
And angelus ad uirginem he song
And aftir þat he sang þe kingꝭes note
Ful often was blist his mery þrote
And þus this swete clerc his time spent
Aft̉er/re his frendis finding and aft̉er/re hˢ rent
¶ This Carpent̉er/re had weddid a new wif
Whom þat he loued as he did his lif
Of xviij yere she was of Age
Ielouse he was and held hir narrow in cage
For she was yong ⁊and wilde and he was olde
And demed himselue forto be A cocold
He knew not Catou for his witt was rude
That badde man wedde his similitude
Men shuld wedde aftir their astate
For youthe and age is often at debate
But sith he was fallen in the Snare
He mut endure as oþir folk dou his car
Feir was this yong wif and therwithall
As any wesil hir body gentil and small
A Seynt she werid y barrid al wᵗith silk
A barm cloth as white as any milke
And upou hir lendis sate many a gore
White was hir smocke ⁊and broudid al bifor
And eke behind on hir coler about
Of cool blac silk wᵗithin and eke wᵗithout
The tapis of hir white volupere
Were of the same sute of hir coler
Hir filet brood of silk and sette ful hie
And sicurli she hadde a licorous iye
Ful smale y pulled were hir browis two
And thei were bent and blac as any slo
She was more blisful vnto see
Than is the new pere Ienet tree
And softer than is the wolle of a feþ̉er/re
And bi hir coot ther hing a purs of leþ̉er/re
Y tasseld wᵗith silke and perlid wᵗith latou
In al this world to seche vp and doun
Þer is no man so wise þᵗat coude thench
So gay a pupplot or such a wench
For brighter was the shinyng of hir hue
Þan in þe tour þe noble y forgid newe
But hir song it was so loude and yern
As any Swalow sitting on a Bern
Þ̉er/reto she coude skippe and made a game
As any kidde or calf folowing his dame
Hir mouth was swete as any bragot or meþe
Or hurde of Appuls leid in hony or heeth
Winsing she was as is a ioly Colt
Long as a Mast and vpright as a bolt
A broche she bare on hir loue coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Hir Shone were lacid on hir leggꝭes hye
She was a primerol a piggisnye
For any lord to ligge in his bedde
Or yit for any good yoman to wedde
Now sir and eft sir so bifill the case
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fil wᵗith this yong wif to rage ⁊and pley
Whils þᵗat hir husbond was at Osney
And clerkis ben sotell and full queint
And pⁱriueli he caught hir bi the Queynt
And seid y wis but if I haue my will
For derne loue of thee leman I spille
And held hir hard bi þe haunche bones
And seid leman loue me wel attones
Or I wil die so god me saue
And she sprang as colt doþ in a tᵃue
And wᵗith hir heed she wried fast awey
She seid I nyl not kisse thee be my fey
Wy labe coth she labee Nicholas
Or I wil crie out harow and alas
Do wey your handis for your curtasi
Þis Nicholas gan mercy forto cry
And spac so feir and ꝓprofird him so fast
Þat she hir loue graunt him at last
And swore hir othe bi seint Thomᵃs of kent
Þᵗat she wold be at his comaundement
Whan þᵗat she may hir leisour wel aspye
Myn husbond is so fulle of Ielousye
Þat but ye wayt wele and be pryuee
I wote right wel I nam but dede ꝙquod she
Ye mut be ful derne as in this caas
Nay therof care you not qd hend nicholas
A clerc had simply bisette his while
But if he couth a carpinter begile
And thus they were acordid and y sworn
To wait a time as ye haue herd aforn
And whan Nicholas had doıı̄un þus eủer/reydel
And thakid hir about the lendis wel
He kissith hir swete than takiþ he hⁱˢ sautry
And pleyeth fast and makith melodye
Þan fil it þus that to the parissh church
Cristis own werkis forto wurche
Þis wif went on an halyday
Hir forhede shone as bryght as any day
So was it wassh whan she lete hir werk
Now was ther of that parissh church A clerk
Which that was y clepid Absolou
Curlid was his here and as gold it shou
And stroutid as a fanne large and brode
Ful streight and euen lay his ioly shood
His Rudde was rede his iyen grey as goos
Wᵗith poules windowe coruen on his shoes
In hosen rede he went fulle fetisly
And girt he was ful smalle and ꝓpropirli
And in a Cote of light wachette
Ful feir and þik ben þe pointꝭes sette
And þ̉er/reuppou he hadde a gay surplice
As white as is þe blossum on þe Rice
A meri man he was as god me saue
Wel coude he lete blood clipp ⁊and shaue
And made a Chart̉er/re of lond or acqⁱtauce
In xxᵗⁱ man he coude trippe ⁊and daunce
Aftir the scole of Oxenforde thoo
And with his leggis cast he to ⁊and fro
And pley songꝭes many on a Ribible
Þ̉er/reto he song sumtime a loude quinyble
And as wel couth he pley on a gitt̉er/rene
In al the Toun nas ther bruhous ne taủer/rene
That he ne visit with his Solace
Ther as any gay Tapster was
But soth to sey he was sumdel squaym9
Of farting and of speche daungerus
Þis Absolon that ioly was and gay
Goth wᵗith a Senser on the haliday
Sensing the wyues of the ꝑper/parissh fast
And many a loueli look on hem cast
And nameli on this carpinters wif
To look on hir him thought a meri lif
She was so ꝓpropre and feir and licorous
I dar wel sey and she had ben A mouse
And he a Catte he wold hir hent anou
This parissh clerk this ioli Absolou
Hath in his hert such a loue longing
That of no wife toke he offringe
For curtasi he seid he wold none
The Mone whan it was night ful briȝt shoıı̄un
And Absolon his gitt̉er/rene hath y take
For paramours he thought forto wake
And furth he goth iolif and amerous
Til he cam to the Carpintꝭess house
A litle aft̉er/re the cockis hadde ycrow
And drest him up by a shot window
Þat was upou the Carpinters wall
He singith in his voice gentle ⁊and small
Now dere ladi if that your wille be
I pray you that ye wil think on me
Ful wel accordaunt to his gitt̉er/renyng
Þis carpint̉er/re awoke and herd him sing
And spac vnto his wif / and seid anou
What Alisou herestow nought Absolou
Þat singith thus vndir our chambre wall
And she answerd hir husbond wᵗithalle
Yis god woot Iohu . I here it eueridel
Þis passith furth what wil ye bet þa wel
From day to day this ioly Absolou
So wowith hir that him is wo bigou
He wakith al the night and al the day
He kembith his lockis ⁊and makiþ him al gay
He wowith hir by meanes and bi brocage
And swore he wold ben hir owne page
He singith brockingꝭes as a nightyngale
He sent hir piment methe and spicid Ale
And wafirs piping hoot out of þe glede
And for she was of toun he ꝓprofird hir mede
For sum folk wil wowe women wᵗith Richesse
And sum with strokis and sum wᵗith gentilnesse
Sumtime to shew his lightnesse and maistrie
He pleyth heroudes upou a Scaffold hye
But what auaileth it him as in this cas
She loueth so this hende Nicholas
Þat Absolon may blowe the buckis horn
He nath for his labour but a . scorn
And thus she makith Absolon hir Ape
And al his ernest turneth to a Iape
Ful true is this ꝓprouerbe and no lye
Men seyn thus alwey the nygh slye

l.hi: Makith the ferre lefe to be lothe

div.l: For though þat Absoloıı̄un be wood or wᵗith
Be cause that he was ferre fro hir sight
Thus nye stood Nicholas in his light
But now bere thee wel hend nicholas
For Absolon may waile and sing alas
And so befil it on a Saturnsday
This carpinter was gon to Osnay
And hende Nicholas and Alisou
Acordid ben to this Conclusiou
That Nicholas shal shape hem a wile
This celi ielous husbond forto begile
And if so be the game went aright
She shuld slepe in his armes al night
For this was his desire and hirs also
And right anou withouten wurdis moo
This nicholas no lenger wold tary
But doth ful soft into his chambir cary
Boþ mete and drink for A day or twey
And bad hir vnto hir husbond seye
If that he askid aftir Nicholas
Þat she shuld sey she nyst wher he was
Of al that day she saw him not wᵗith iye
She trowid that he was in sum malady
For for no crie hir maid couth him call
He nold answere for thing that might befall
¶This passith furth alle that Saturday
Þat nicholas stille in his chambur lay
And ete and slept and did what him lest
Til Sunday that the Sunne goth to rest
This celi Carpinter had gret muayle
Of Nicholas what thing might him ayle
And seid I am adredde by seint Thomas
It stant not aright with hende Nicholas
God shield that he died sodeynly
The world is now ful tikil sicurly
I sye today a cors boru to chirch
Þat on monday last I sye him wirch
Go up ꝙquod he vnto his knave anone
Clepe at his dore or knocke fast wᵗitha stou
Look hou it is and telle me boldely
His knaue goth up fulle Sturdily
And at chambir dore whils þᵗat he stode
He cried and knocked as he were wode
What how what do ye maistir Nicholay
Hou may ye slepe alle the long day
But al for nought he herd not a worde
An hool he founde ful lowe upou a borde
Þ̉er/re the catte was wont in forto crepe
And at þat hool he lokid in ful depe
And at last he hadde of him a sight
Þis nicholas sate eủer/re gaping upright
As he had kekid on the new mone
A doun he goth and told his maist̉er/re sone
In what array he sye this ilke man
This carpinter to blis him tho began
And seid now helpe us seint Frideswide
A man woot litle what him shal betide
Þis man is yfalle with his Astronomye
In sum woodnesse or in sum agonye
I thought ay wele hou that it shuld be
Men shuld not know of goddis pⁱriuite
Ye blissid be alweye a lewde man
That nought but only his bileve canne
Right so ferd Anothir clerk wᵗith Astᵒnomy
He walkid in the feldis forto prye
Vpou the Sterris / what ther shuld befall
Til he was in a marle pitte y falle
He sye not that but yit bi seint Thomᵃs
Me rueth sore of hende Nicholas
He shal be ratid out of his studying
If that I may by the heuen kyng
Gete me a staffe that I may vndirspore
Whils that thou Robin heuest vp the dore
He shal out of his studiyng I gesse
And to his chambir dore he him dresse
His knaue was a strong carle for þe nones
And bi the haspe bare vp the dore attones
And into the flore the dore fille anou
Þis Nicholas sate ay as stille as stone
And euer gapid upward to the ayer
Þis carpinter wend he wer in dispeir
And hent him bi his shuldirs mightily
And shook him hard ⁊and cried spitously
What nicholas what how look a doun
Awake and think on cristis passioun
I crouche thee from Elues ⁊and fro wikid wiȝtꝭes
Þ̉er/rewᵗith the night spell seid he anou rightis
On iiij halues of the hous aboute
And on the thresshold of the dore wᵗithout
Ihus crist and seint Benedight
Blesse this hous from eủer/rey wikid wiȝt
For the night mare the white pr nost̉er/re
Where wentest thou seint pet̉er/res sustir
And at laste this hende Nicholas
Gan forto sigh sore and seide alas
Shal alle the world be lost eft sones now
Þis carpinter ansuerd what seyest þou
What think on god as dou we men þᵗat swink
Þis nicholas ansuerd now fecch me drynk
And aftir wil I speke in pryuite
Of certein þingis þᵗat touchen þee ⁊and me
I nyl tel it none othir man certeyn
Þis carpinter goth doun ⁊and comeþ ageyn
And brought of ale a large quarte
And whan þat eche man had drunk hⁱˢ part
Þis nicholas his dore fast Shette
And doun the carpinter bi him he sette
And seid Iohu myne host leef and dere
Þou shat upou thyne othe swere here
Þat to no wight þou shat my counceil wrey
For it is cristis counceil that I seye
⁊and if thou telle it any man þᵘ art forlor
For þis vengeaunce shaltou haue þ̉er/refor
Þat if þou wrey me þou shat be wood
Nay crist forbede it for his holi blood
Qd the celi man I nam no blabbe
And þough I sey it I am not leef to gab
Sey what þou wit I shal it neuer tell
To wif ne child / bi him þat harowd hell
Now Iohn qd þis nicholas I nyl not lye
I haue founden in myne Astrologie
Þat now on monday next at quart̉er/re night
For I haue lokid in the mone so bright
Shal falle a Reyne and þat so wilde ⁊and wode
Þat half so gret was neuer Noes flood
Þis world he seid in lasse þan an hour
Shal al be dreint so hidous is the shour
Þus shal mankinde drenche ⁊and lese her lif
Þis carpint̉er/re ansuerd alas my wif
And shal she droun alas myn Alisou
For sorou of this he fil almost adoun
And seid is ther no remedie in þis cas
Wy yis for god qd hende Nicholas
If thou wit wurch aftir lore and rede
Þou maist not wurch aft̉er/re þine ovn hede
For þus seiþ Salamou þat was ful true
Wurch al bi counceil ⁊and þou shat not rue
And if þou wurch wil bi good counceil
I vndirtake wᵗithouten mast or Seyle
Yit shal I saue hir and me and tee
And hastou not herd hou saued was noe
Whan þat oure lord had warned him aforn
Þat al the world wᵗith wat̉er/re shuld be lorne
Yis qd þis carpint̉er/re full yore Agoo
Hastou not herde coth nicholas also
Þe sorou of noe with his felaship
Or þat he gete might his wif to shipp
Him hadde be leuer I vndirtake
At that time than al his wethirs blake
Þat she had hadde A Shippe hirselue alone
And therfore wostow what is best to dou
Þis askith hast and of hasty thing
Men may not preche ⁊and make a tariyng
Anone go gete vs fast into this ynne
A kneding trowgh or ellis a kemelin
For eche of us / but loke þᵗat thei be large
In which þat we may swymme as in a barge
And haue theryn vitaile sufficiant
But for a day . fy on the Remenant
Þe watir shal aslake and go away
About prime vpoıı̄un the next Day
But Robin may not wit of þˢ þi knave
Nor yit thi maid gille I may not saue
Ax not whi for þough þou axe me
I nyll not telle of goddis priuite
It sufficith thee . but if thi wit is badde
To haue as gret a grace as Noe hadde
Þi wif shal I wel saue out of dout
Go now thi wey and spede thee her about
But whan þou hast for hir ⁊and thee ⁊and me
Y goten us the kneding tubbis thre
Þan shaltou hang hem in þe Roof ful hye
So þat noman of oure purpos aspye
And whan þou þus hast done as I of seid
And hast oure vitaile feir in hem leid
And eke an Axe to smyte þe cordis atwo
Whan þat þe watir comes þᵗat we may go
An breke an hool an hye upoıı̄un the gable
Vnto þe gardenward ouer þe Stable
Þat we may freli pas furth oure wey
Whan the gret shoure is gone awey
Þan shaltou swymme as mery I vndtake
As doth the white Doke aftir the Drake
Þan wil I clepe how Alisoıı̄un how Iohn
Be mery for þe flood wil passe anoıı̄un
And þou wilt sey heil maistir nicholay
Good morow for I se wele it is day
And þan shul we be lordis alle our lif
Of al þe world / as Noe and his wif
But of one thyng I warne þee ful right
Be wele avisid on that ilke nyght
Þat we ben entird into þᵉ ship bord
Þat none of vs ne speke one word
Ne clepe ne crye but be in his pᵃyere
For it is goddis ovne heste Dere
Thi wif and þou must hang ferr atwyn
For þat betwyx you shal be no synne
No more in loking þan þ̉er/re shal in dede
Þis ordinaunce is eid go god you spede
Tomorn at night whan men ben al a slepe
Into oure kneding tubbis þan wil we crepe
And sitte ther abiding goddis grace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger ʆser/sirmonyng

l.hi: Men seyn þus send þe wise ⁊and sey no þing

div.l: Þou art so wise it nedith þee not to teche
Go saue oure livis and þat I þee beseche
¶ This celi carpinter goþ furþ on hˢ wey
Ful often he seid alas and welawey
And to his wife he told his priuite
And she was war and knew it bet þa he
What al this queint cast was to seye
But naþeles she ferd as she wold deye
And seid alas go furth thi wey anone
Help us to scape or we ben dede echou
I am thi true verai weddid wife
Go dere spouse and help to saue oᵘur lif
Lo which a gret thing is affecciou
Men may die of ymaginacioun
So depe may impressiou be take
Þis celi carpint̉er/re begynneþ to quake
Him þinkith verali that he may see
Noes flood com waltring as þe See .
To drench Alisou his hony Dere
He wepith he wailith ⁊and makiþ sori cher
He sighith wᵗith many A sory swough
And goth and getith him a kneding trogh
And aftir a tubbe or a kemelyn
And pryueli he sent hem to his ynne
And hangid hem in the Roof in priuite
And wᵗith his own hand he made laddirs þre
To clymbe bi the Rungis and the stalkis
Into the tubbis hanging in the Balkis
And hem vitail boþe in trogh and tubbe
And breed and chese and good ale in a Iubbe
Sufficing right ynough as for a Day
But or þat he had made al this array
He sent his knaue and his wench also
Vpou his nede to londou forto goo
⁊and on þe monday whan it drue to night
He shet his dore wᵗithouten candel light
And dressid al thing as it shuld be
And shortly up thei clymbe alle thre
Þei sate stille not fully a furlong wey
Now pater noster clum seid nicholay
And clum qd Iohn and clum seid Alisou
This carpinter than seid his deuocōmn
And stille he sitte and bit prayere
Awaiting on the Reyne if he might it her
Til the dede slepe for wery ⁊and for bisinesse
Felle on the carpinter right as I gesse
About curfue time or a litle more
For trauel of his gost he traueild sore
And often he routid for his hede mys lay
And then doun of the laddir stalkiþ nicholay
And Alisou soft adoun she hir spedde
Wᵗithout wurdis mo thei gou to bedde
There as the carpinter is wont to lye
There was moch reuel and melody
And þus lith Alisoıı̄un and hend nicholas
In bisinesse of mirth and of solas
Til that the belle of laudis gan ringe
And freris in þe chauncel gan sing /
¶This parissh clerc þis amero9 Absolou
That is for loue salwey so woo bigou
Vpou the monday was at Osney
Wᵗith cumpani him to disport and pley
And axith upou caas of the cloystrer
Ful priueli aftir Iohn the Carpinter
And he drue him a part out of þe chirch
And seid I note I sye him not wirch
Syn Saturdai . I . trow he be went
For timbir ther oure abbot haþ him sent
For he is wont for timbir forto goo
And bide at graungis aday or two
Or ellis he is at his house certeyn
Where that he be I can not soþli seyn
¶This Absolou ful ioli was and light
And þought now is time to wake al night
For sicurly I sawe him not stiryng
About his dore sith day began spring
So mut I thryue I shal or cockꝭescrow
Ful pryueli knok at his wyndowe
Þat stant ful low upou his bouris wall
To alison now wille I telle alle
My loue longing for yit I shal not mys
Þat at lest wey I shalle hir kysse
Sum maner cumfort shal I haue ꝑper/parfay
My mouth hath icchid alle this day
Þat is a signe of kissing at the lest
Al night me mette þat I was at a fest
Þ̉er/refore I wil go slepe an hour or tuey
And al the night I wil go walk ⁊and pley
And whan þat þe first cocke haþ crow anou
Vp risith this ioly louer Absoloıı̄un
And him arayeth gay and point deuise
But first he chewith greyn ⁊and licorise
To smelle soot or he had kembid hˢ her
And vndir his tung atruloue he bere
For therfore wend he to be gracious
He rometh furth to the carpint̉er/res hous
And stil he stant vndir þe shot windou
Vnto his brest it raught it was so low
And soft he coughid wᵗith a semy soun
What do ye hony combe my swete Alisou
My feir bird my swete sinamomee
Awakith leman myn and spekiþ to me
Ful litle think ye vpou my woo
For for your loue I swelt þ̉er/re I go
No wundir is þough I swelt or swete
I mourn as doth þe lamme aft̉er/re þe tete
I wis leman I haue such loue longing
Þat like a turtil true is my mournyng
I may ete no more þan may a mayde
Go fro the windou Iac fool she said
As help me god it nyl not be cum bame
I loue anothir and ellis I wer to blame
Wel bett þan thee bi ihu . Absoloıı̄un
Go furth thi wey or I wil cast a stou
And lat me slepe a twenti Deuel wey
Alas qd absolon and wele away
Þat truloue was euer so bisette
Þan kis me syn it may be no bette
For ihu loue and for the loue of me
Wilt thou go thi wey therwᵗith qd she
Ye certis leman coth this Absolou
Þan make thee redi qd she I com anoıı̄un
Þis absolon doun sette him on hˢ knees
And seid I am a lord at all Degrees
For aft̉er/re this I hoop ther comeþ mor
Leman thi grace and swete bird þyne or
The windou she vndoth and þat in hast
Haue don qd she and spede thee fast
Lest that myne neybours thee aspye
Þis absolon gan wipe his mouþ ful dry
Derk was the night as picch or cole
And at last she put out hir hool
And absolon him felt bette ne wers
But wᵗith his mouth he kist hir bar ars
Ful sauourli or he were war of þis
Abak he stert as though it was a mys
Ful wel he wist a woman hath no berd
For he felt a thing alle rough ⁊and long herd
And seid fy alas what haue I doo
Te he qd she and clapt þe windou to
And absolon goth furth a sory paas
A berd a berd seid hende Nicholas
Bi goddis corpus this goþ feir ⁊and wel
This celi absolon herde euerydel
And on his lippe he gan for ang byte
And to himselue he seid I shal þe quite
Who rubbiþ now who frotiþ his lippis
Wᵗith dust wᵗith Sand wᵗith cloth ⁊and wᵗith chippꝭes
But absolon . þat seiþ ful often alas
My soule betake I to thee Sathanas
But me wer leủer/re þan al this toun ꝙquod he
Of this dispite y wroken forto be
Alas coþ he alas I nadde y bleynt
His hoot loue was cold and al y queint
For fro þat time he had y kist hir ers
Of paramoures he sette not a kers
For he was y helid of his maladye
Ful often ꝑper/paramours he can defye
And wept as a child that is y bete
A soft paas he went oủer/re the strete
Vnto a smyth men clepid Ierueis
Þat in his forge smithid plouȝ harneis
He sharpith share and cultir bisili
This absolon knockith alle esily
Þan spac this Ierueis ⁊and þat anou
What who artow . it am I absolou
What absolon for cristis dere tre
Whi arise ye so rathe ey bndicite
What ailith you sum gay gerl god it wote
Hath brought you þus upou þe very tote
Bi seint nutte ye wote wel what I mene
Þis absolon rought not of a Bene
Of al his pleye . ne word ageyn he yaf
He hadde more towe on his Distaffe
Þan Ierueis knew / and seid frend so der
Þe hoot cultur in the chymney here
As lene it me I haue therwᵗith to dou
I wil bring it and þat ageyn right sone
Ierveis seid certis were it gold
Or in a pook nobles alle vntold
Thou shuldist haue it as I am true Smyth
Ey cristis foo what wil ye do ther wᵗith
Ther of coth Absolon be as be may
I shal wel tel it thee or to morn day
And caught the cultir by the cold stele
Ful soft out at the Dore he gan stele
And went vnto the carpinters walle
He cought first and knockid ther wᵗithall
Vpon the windou right as he did eer
Þis alisoıı̄un ansuerd who is there
Þat knockith so y wariant he is A þeef
We nay qd he I warant my swete leef
I am thine absolou thi dere Derling
Of gold ꝙquod he I haue thee brought a Ring
My modir gaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyne it is and therto wel y gᵃue
Þis wil I yeue you and ye wil me kisse
Þis Nicholas was y risen al forto pisse
And þought he wold amend al the iape
He shuld kis his ars ere þat he furþ̉er/re scape
And up the windou did he hastily
And out his ers he putte ful pⁱriuely
And oủer/re the buttok to the haunche bone
And þ̉er/rewith spak this clerk this absolou
Speke swete birde I note wher þou art
Þis nicholas anone lete flee a fart
As gret as it had ben a thundir dynt
Þat wᵗith the strook he was wel ny blynt
Þan he was redi with his Iren hoot
And nicholas in the toute he smote
Of goth the skynne an handbrede about
Þe hoot cultir brennyng in his tout
And for the smert he wend forto dye
As he were wood for wo began to cry
Help watir help for goddis hert
Þis carpinter out of his slepe stert
And herd one cry watir as he wer wode
And thought alas now comeþ noes flode
And sette him up withouten wurdis moo
And with an axe he smote the cordis atwo
And doun goþ alle / he found neithir to selle
Brede ne ale . but shortly doun he felle
Vpou the flore . and there in swow he lay
Vpstert alisou and hend Nicholay
And cried out and harow in the strete
Than the neybours boþ smale ⁊and grete
Ben comen forto gaure on this man
Þat in swow lay white palissh ⁊and wan
For wᵗith that falle borsten had he hˢ arm
But stond he must vnto his ovn harme
For whan he spak he was born a doun
With hend nicholas and Alisoun
They told euery man þat he was wode
He was agast so of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasy that of his natiuite
He had goten hym tubbis three
And had hem hangid in the rofe aboue
And that hem for goddis loue
To sitte in the Roof ꝑper/par cumpany
The folk gan laugh at his fantasy
And to the Rofe they kiken ⁊and þei gape
And turned al his harm vnto a Iape
For what so this carpinter ansuerd
It was for nought no man his resou herd
With othis gret he was y born adoun
Þat he was holden wode in alle þe toun
For eủer/rey clerk anou held with othir
Þey seid the man was wode my lef broþ̉er/re
And euery wight can laugh at þis strif
Thus ʆser/sirued was the carpinters wife
For al his keping and his Ielousye
And Absolon hath kist hir nethir iye
And nicholas is scallid in his toute
This tale is done ⁊and god saue al þe Rout
¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
As any pecok he was proud and gay
pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
And by his belt he baar a long panade
And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
Round was his face and camuse was his nose
As piled as an Ape was his skulle
He was a Market beter at the fulle
Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
The person of the toun hir fader was
With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
And she was proud and peert as is a pye
A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
And she cam after in a gyte of reed
And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
And eek for she was som del smoterlich
She was as digne as water in a dich
And ful of hoker and of bismare
Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
The person of the toun for she was so feir
In purpos was to maken hir his heir
Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
For holicherches good moot been despended
On holicherches blood that is descended
Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
With whete and malt of al the land aboute
And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
An hondred tyme moore than biforn
For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
They makyn redy al hir owen gere
And on an hors the sak he caste anon
Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
By god right by the hoper wol I stande
Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
How that the hoper wagges til and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wiltow swa
Thanne wol I be byneth by my crown
And se how that the mele falles down
In to the trogh that sal be my desport
For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort
I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
They wene that no man may hem bigile
But by my thrift yet shal I blere hir Iye
For al the sleighte in hir phislophye
The moore queynte crekys that they make
The moore wol I stele whan I take
In stede of flour yet wol I yeue hem bren
The grettest clerkes been noght the wisest men
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of al hir art counte I noght a tare
Out of the dore he gooth ful pryuely
Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde
Bihynde the Mille vnder a leefsel
And to the hors he gooth hym faire and wel
He strepeth of the bridel right anon
And whan the hors was laus he gynneth gon
Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
And forth with wehe thurgh thikke and thenne
This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde
But dooth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
Til that hir corn was faire and wel ygrounde
And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away
And gan to crye harrow and weilaway
Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde his housbondrye
What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren
She seyde allas youre hors gooth to the fen
With wilde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthank come on his hand that boond hym so
And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne
Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne
Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa
I is ful wight god waat as is a ra
By god hert he sal nat scape vs bathe
Be cockis herte he shal not a scape vs bathe
Why ne had thow pit the capil in the lathe
Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne
This sely clerkes haan ful faste yronne
Toward the fen bothe Alayn and eek Iohn
And whan the Millere seigh that they were gon
He half a busshel of hir flour hath take
And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
He seyde I trowe the clerkes were aferd
Yet kan a Millere maken a clerkes berd
For al his art ye lat hem goon hir weye
Lo wher he gooth ye lat the children pleye
They gete hym noght so lightly by my croun
Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun
With keep keep stand stand Iossa warderere
Ga whistle thow and I sal kepe hym heere
But shortly til that it was verray nyght
They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght
Hir capyl cacche he ran alwey so faste
Til in a dych they caughte hym at the laste
Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
And namely the Millere weilawey
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond
The Millere sittyng by the fyr he fond
For it was nyght and ferther myghte they noght
But for the loue of god they hym bisoght
Of herberwe and of ese as for hir peny
The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
Ye kan by argumentz make a place
A myle brood of twenty foot of space
Lat se now if this place may suffise
Or make it rowm with speche as is your gyse
Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende
This Millere in to town his doghter sende
For ale and breed and rosted hem a goos
And boond hir hors it sholde namoore go loos
And in his owene chambre hem made a bed
With shetes and with chalons faire yspred
Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue
Right in the same chambre by and by
It myghte be no bet and cause why
Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
They soupen and they speken hem to solace
And drynken euere stroong ale at the beste
Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
Wel hath this Millere vernysshed his heed
Ful pale he was for dronke and noght reed
He yexeth and he speketh thurgh the nose
As he were on the quakke or on the pose
To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wyf
As any Iay she light was and iolyf
So was hir ioly whistle wel ywet
The Cradel at hir beddes feet is set
To rokken and to yeue the child to sowke
And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
To bedde wente the doghter right anon
To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale
That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleep
Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong
The wenche routeth eek per compaignye
Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye
He poked Iohn and seyde slepest thow
Herd thow euere slyk a sang er now
Lo swilk a couplyng is ymel hem alle
A wilde fyr on thair bodyes falle
Wha herkned euere swilk a ferly thyng
Ye they sal haue the flour of il endyng
This lang nyght ther tydes me na reste
But yet na force al sal be for the beste
For Iohn seyde he als euere moot I thryue
If that I may yon wenche wol I swyue
Som esement has lawe shapen vs
For Iohn ther is a lawe that says thus
That gif a man in a point be agreued
That in another he sal be releued
Oure corn is stoln soothly it is na nay
And we han had an ille fit to day
And syn I sal haue naan amendement
Agayn my los I wil haue esement
By goddes saule it sal naan other be
This Iohn answerde Aleyn auyse thee
The Millere is a perilous man he sayde
And if that he out of his sleep abrayde
He myghte doon vs bathe a vileynye
Aleyn answerde I counte hym noght a flye
And vp he rist and by the wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vp righte and faste slepte
Til he so neigh was er she myghte espie
That it hadde been to late for to crie
And shortly for to seyn they were at oon
Now pley Aleyn for I wol speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille a furlang wey or two
And to hym self he maketh routhe and wo
Allas quod he this is a wikked Iape
Now may I seyn that I is but an ape
Yet has my felawe som what for his harm
He has the Milleris doghter in his arm
He auntred hym and has his nedes sped
And I lye as a draf sak in my bed
And whan this iape is told another day
I sal ben halden a daf a Cokenay
I wil arise and auntre it by my fayth
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
And vp he roos and softely he wente
Vn to the Cradel and in his hand it hente
And baar it softe vn to his beddes feet
Soone after this the wyf hir routynt leet
And gan awake and wente hir out to pisse
And cam agayn and gan hir Cradel mysse
And groped heer and ther but she foond noon
Allas quod she I hadde almoost mysgoon
I hadde almoost goon to the clerkes bed
Ey benedicite thanne had I foule ysped
And forth she gooth til she the Cradel fond
She gropeth alwey forther with hir hond
And foond the bed and thoghte noght but good
By cause that the Cradel by it stood

l.seg: And nyste wher sche was for it was derk

div.l: And nyste wher she was for it was derk
But faire and wel she creep in to the clerk
And lyth ful stille and wolde haue caught a sleep
With Inne a while this Iohn the clerk vp leep
And on this goode wyf he leyth on soore
So murie a fyt ne hadde she nat ful yoore
He priketh harde and depe as he were mad
This ioly lyf han thise two clerkes lad
Til that the thridde cok bigan to synge
Aleyn wax wery in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonken al the longe nyght
And seyde fare wel Malyn swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger byde
But euere mo wher so I go or ryde
I is thyn awen clerk so haue I sel
Now deere lemman quod she go farewel
But er thow go o thyng I wol thee telle
Whan that thow wendest homward by the Melle
Right at the entree of the dore bihynde
Thow shalt a Cake of half a busshel fynde
That was ymaked of thyn owene mele
Which that I heelp my sire for to stele
And good lemman god thee saue and kepe
And with that word almoost he gan to wepe
Aleyn vp rist and thoghte er that it dawe
I wol go crepen In by my felawe
And fond the Cradel with his hond anon
By god thoghte he al wrang I haue mysgon
Myn heed is toty of my swynk to nyght
That maketh me that I go noght aright
I woot wel by the Cradel I haue mysgo
Here lyth the Millere and his wyf also
And forth he gooth on twenty deueleway
Vn to the bed ther as the Millere lay
He wende haue cropen by his felawe Iohn
And by the Millere In he creep anoon
And caughte hym by the nekke and softe he spak
He seyde thou Iohn thow swyneshed awak
For cristes saule and here a noble game
For by that lord that called is Seint Iame
As I haue thries in this shorte nyght
Swyued the Milleris doghter bolt vp right
Whil thow hast as a coward been agast
Ye false harlot quod the Millere hast
Ye false harlot hast thou so hest
A false traytour false clerk quod he
Thou shalt be deed by goddes dignytee
Who dorste be so bold to disparage
My doghter that is come of swich lynage
And by the throte bolle he caughte Alayn
And he hente hym despitously agayn
And on the nose he smoot hym with his fest
Doun ran the blody streem vp on his brest
And on the floor with nose and mouth tobroke
They walwen as doon two pigges in a poke
And vp they goon and doun agayn anoon
Til that the Millere sporned on a stoon
And doun he fil bakward vp on his wyf
That wiste no thyng of this nyce stryf
For she was falle aslepe alitel wight
With Iohn the clerk that waked hadde al nyght
And with the fal out of hir sleep she brayde
Help holy cros of Bromholm she sayde
In manus tuas lord to thee I calle
Awake Symond the feend is on me falle
Myn herte is broken help I nam but ded
Ther lyth oon vp on my wombe and vp myn hed
Help Symkyn for the false clerkes fighte
This Iohn sterte vp as faste as euere he myghte
And graspeth by the walles to and fro
To fynde a staf and she sterte vp also
And knew the estres bet than dide this Iohn
And by the wal a staf she foond anon
And saugh a litel shymeryng of a light
For at an hole in shoon the moone bright
And by that light she saugh hem bothe two
But sikerly she nyste who was who
But as she saugh a whit thyng in hir Iye
And whan she gan this white thyng espye
She wende the clerk hadde wered a voluper
And with the staf she drow ay ner and ner
And wende han hit this Aleyn at the fulle
And smoot the Millere on the piled skulle
That doun he gooth and cryde harrow I dye
Thise clerkes bette hym wel and lete hym lye
And greithen hem and tooke hir hors anon
And eek hir mele and on hir wey they gon
And at the Mille yet they toke hir cake

She seid she was maȝid in the See
Þat she forgat hir mynde bi hir trouth
The Constable hath of hir so gret pite
And eke his wif þᵗat thei wepid for routh
She was so diligent wᵗithouten slouthe
To ʆser/sirue and to pleas echon in that place
That al hir loued þat loken in hir face
The Constable and dame hermengild hˢ wif
Were payneins / as þatcuntrey eủer/remor̉er/re wer̉er/re
But hermengild loued hir right as hir lif
And Constaunce hath so long soiournd þer̉er/re
In orisons wᵗith many a bittir teere
Til ihu hath conủer/retid þurgh his grace
Dame hermengild constablesse of þᵗat place
In alle that lond no cⁱsten durst arrout
Al cristen folk ben flewe fro þᵗat cuntree
Þurghpayneins þatconquerd al about
The plages of the northlond and See
Vnto wales went the Cristiantee
Of olde Britons duelling in this Ile
Ther̉er/re was their̉er/re refute for þᵉ mene while
But they neủer/re cristen britoıı̄uns exilid
Þat þer nere sume þatin their̉er/re priuite
Honoured crist and hethen thei begilid
And nye the castel such þer̉er/re duellid þre
Þat one of hem was blinde ⁊and might not se
But if it were wᵗiththe iye of his mynde

l.hi: Wᵗithwhich men sene when þei be blinde

div.l: Bright was the sonne as the som day
For wᵗithich the Constable and his wif also
And Constaunce hantaken the rightway
Toward þe see a furlong wey or two
To pleye and to room too and froo
And in their̉er/re walk þe blinde man þei mette
Crokid and olde wᵗith iyen fast y shette
In the name of crist cried this blinde Bretoıı̄un
Dame hermengild yeue me my sight ageyne
The ladi wext affraid of the sovne
Lest that hir husbond shortli forto seyn
Wold hir for cristis loue haue sleyne
Til Constaunce made hir bold ⁊and bad hir wirch
Þe wille of crist as doughtir of holi chirch
The Constable wex abasshid of that sight
And seid what amountith alle this fare
Constaunce ansuerd ⁊and seid itis cristis might
Þat helpith folk out of the fendis snare
And so ferfurth she gan the ladi declare
Þat she the constable or thatitwas Eue
Conủer/retid and on crist made him beleue
This Constable was nothing lord of þis place
Of which I speke ther̉er/re as he constaunce fond
But kept it strongli many wintirs space
Vndir Alla king of alle Northumbirlond
Þat was ful wise and wurthi of his hond
Ageyn the Scottis / as men may wele here
Butturne I wil ageyn to my matere
Sathan that eủer/re us waiteth to begile
Saw of Constaunce alle hir ꝑper/parfeccoıı̄un
And cast anone hou he might quite hir while
And made a yong knight þᵗatduelt in þᵗat toun
Loue hir as hote of foule affeccioun
Þatverily him þought he shuld spille
But he of hir might ones haue hiswill
He wowithhir but it availith nought
She nold do no synne by no weye
And for despite he cumpast in his thought
To make hir on shameful dethe to deye
He waitith whan þe constable was awey
And priueli upon a night he crepte
In hermengildis chambir while she slept
Wery forwakid in theire Orisoıı̄uns
Slepith constaunce ⁊and hermengild also
Þis knight þurgh satanas temptacoıı̄uns
Alle softely is vnto bedde y goo
And cutte þe throte of hermengild a two
And leid the blodi knife bi dame constaunce
And went his wey þ̉er/re god yeue him mischaıı̄unce
Sone aftir comeþ þe constable home ageyn
And eke Alla that king was of that lond
And saw his wif dispitously slayne
And ofthewept and wrang his hond
And in the bedde the blodi knife he fond
Bi dame Constaunce alas whatshe mightsey
For veray wo hir witte was alle aweye
To king Alla was told alle this mischaunce
And eke the time and where ⁊and in what wyse
Þat in a shippe was founde þis constaunce
As here beforn ye han herd deuise
The kingis hert of pite gan agrise
Whan he saw so benyngne a creature
Falle in dissese and mysauenture
For as the lambe toward his deþe is brought
So stantthis innocent before the king
Þis falsknight þat hath þis tresoıı̄unwrouȝt
Berithhir in hand þat she hath don þˢ þing
But naþeles ther was gret mournyng
Among the peple and seyn þei can not gesse
Þat she had done so grete a wickidnesse
For thei han seyn hir euer̉er/re so vertuous
And louyng hermengild right as hir life
Of this bare wittnesse eủer/reych in that hous
Saue he þat hermengild slough wᵗithhis knife
This gentil king haþ caught a gret motife
Of this wittnesse ⁊and þought he wold enquer̉er/re
Depper̉er/re in this case the trouth to lere
Alas Constaunce þou nast no Champioıı̄un
Ne fight canstow not wele away
But he þat starf for oure redempcōmn
And bounde sathan and yit lith þ̉er/re he lay
So be thi strong champioıı̄un this day
For but crist miracle upon thee kiþe
Withouten gilt thou shalt be slain as swiþe
She sate hir doun on knees ⁊and þus she seid
Inmortal god þat sauedist Susanne
From fals blame ⁊and þou mciful maid
Marie I mene doughtir to seint Anne
Bifore whos child aungels sing osanne
If I be giltles of this Fellonye
My socour̉er/re be or ellis shalle I dye
Haue ye not seyn sumtime a pale face
Among the prees of him þᵗathaþ ben ladde
Toward his dethe wher̉er/re as him gat no gᵃce
And such a colour̉er/re in his face hath hadde
Men might know his face þat was bestadde
Amongꝭes alle the facis in that Route
So stant constaunce and lokith hir about
O Qwenes lyving in prosperite
Duchesses and eke ladies euerichon
Haueþ sum ruthe of hir aduersite
An Emꝑper/parours doughtir stant allon
She nath no wiȝtwhom to make hir mone
O blood rial that stondist in this drede
Ferre ben thi frendis atthi grete nede
This Alla king hath such compassioıı̄un

l.hi: As gentil hert is fulfillid of pitee

div.l: That from his iyen ranne the watir doun
Now hastili do fecche a book quod he
And if this knight wil swere hou that she
Þis woman slue yitwil we us deuise
Whom that we wil that shal be our̉er/re Iustice
A Britoıı̄un book writen with Euᵃngelies
Was fette and on this book he swore anon
She gilty was and in the mene whiles
An hand him smote upon the nekke bon
Þat doun he fille attones as a Stone
And boþe his iyen brast out of his face
In sight of euery bodi in that place
A voyce was herd in genal audience
And seid thou hast disclaundird giltles
The doughtir of holichurche in high psence
Þus hastow done and yithold I my pes
Of þis mueil agast was alle the prees
As maȝid folk thei stoden euerichone
For drede of wreche saue constance allon
Greet was the drede and eke þe repentaunce
Of hem thathadde wrong suspecioıı̄un
Vpon this celi innocent Constaunce
And for this miracle in Conclusioıı̄un
And by Constaunces mediacioıı̄un
Þe king and many anoþir in þᵗat place
Conuertid was þankid be goddis gᵃce
This fals knight was slain for his vntrouth
By Iugement of king Alla hastily
And yit constaunce had of his deþ gret routh
And aftir this Ihus of his mercy
Made Alla to wedde fulle solempnely
Þis wo holi woman so bright ⁊and shene
And thus haþ crist made constaunce a quene
¶ But who was wofulle if I shall not lye
Of þis weddyng but doniegild and no moo
The kinges modir fulle of tirrannye
Hir þought hir cursid hert barst in two
She wold not hir sonne had done so
She þought a despite þathe shuld take
So straunge a creature to his make
Me list not of the chaffe or of þe stree
Make so long a tale as of the corne
What shuld I tellen you of the rialtee
At mariages / and which cours goþ beforn
Who blowithbest in a trump or in an horn
Þe frute of euery tale is forto seye
Thei ete and drink sing daunce ⁊and pleye
Thei gon to bedde as it was skill ⁊and right
For though þat wifes don ful holi þinges
Þei mut take in pacience a night
Such man necessaries as ben plesinges
To folk þat haıı hem weddid wᵗithRinges
And ley a litil their holynes a side
As for the time it mai no bette betide
On hir he gat a man childe anone
And to a busshop and his constable eke
He took his wif to kepe whan he is gon
To Scotlondward his fomen forto seke
Now feire constaunce þᵗat is so humble ⁊and meke
So long is gone wᵗith child til that stille
She halt hir chambir abiding cristꝭes wil
The time is comen A manchild she bere
Mauricius atfontstone men him calle
This constable deþ furþ com a messagere
And wrote vnto his king þᵗat clepid was Alle
Hou þat this blisful tiding is befalle
And oþir tidinges spedefulle forto seye
He hath þe letters and furþ he goþ hˢ wey
This messanger̉er/re to do his a vauntage
Vnto the kingis modir rideth swithe
And salueth hir feire in his langage
Madame coth he ye mai be gladde and blithe
And thank god an hundird thousand sithe
My ladi the quene hath child wᵗithouten dout
To ioye and blis of this Reaine aboute
Lo here the lettirs sealid of this thing
Þat I must bere wᵗithall the hast I may
If ye wil oughtvnto your sone þe king
I am your ʆser/siruaunt bothe night and day
Dame doniegild ansuerd atthis time nay
But here al night I wil þou take þi Rest
To morn wil I sey thee what me lest
¶ This messang drank sadli ale ⁊and wyne
And stolen were his letters pⁱriuelye
Out of his box while he slept as a swyne
And countirfetid was fulle subtily
Anoþ̉er/re lettir wrought fulle synfully
Vnto the king direct of this mater̉er/re
From his Constable as ye shul aft̉er/reher̉er/re
The lre spak the Quene deliued was
Of so horrible a fendly Creature
Þat in the castel none so hardi was
Þat eny while durst theryn endure
Þe modir was an elfe by auenture
Ycomen bi charmes or by sorcery
And euerich hatith hir cumpany
Wo was this king whan he þˢ lre had seyn
But to no wight he told his sorows sore
But of his ovne hand he wrote ageyn
Welcum the sonde of crist for eủer/remore
To me þat am now lerned in his lore

l.hi: Lord welcum be thi lust ⁊and thi plesaunce
My trust I putte alle in thyne ordinaıı̄unce

div.l: Kepith this child al be it foule or feyre
And eke my wyfe vnto my home comyng
Crist whan him list mai sende me an heir̉er/re
More agreable than þis to my liking
This lettir he ensealith priuely weping
Which to the messanger̉er/re was take sone
And furth he goth ther̉er/re is no more to don
This messanger̉er/re comethfro the king ageyn
And atthe kingis modirs hous he light
And she was ofthis messanger̉er/re ful fayn
And pleasid him in al that euer she might
He drank and wele his curtil vndirpight
He slepith and he fnortith in his gyse
Al night til the sonne gan aryse
Eft were his lres y stolen ageyne echon
And countirfetid lettirs in this voise
The king comaundith his constable anon
Vp peyn of hanging and of hye Iuwise
Þat he ne shuld suffre in no wise
Constaunce wᵗithin his Reaine to abide
Thre dayes and a quartir̉er/re of a tide
But in the same Shippe as he hir fond
Hir and hir yong sonne and al hir gere
He shuld putte / and croude hir fro þe lond
And charge hir þat she neuer eft com þer̉er/re
O my constaunce wel may thi gosthaue fer̉er/re
And sleping in thi dreme haue penaunce
Whan Doniegild cast alle this ordinaunce
This messanger̉er/re a morow whan he awoke
Vnto the castel haldith the nextweye
And to the constable he the lettirs toke
And whan that he this pitous lettir seye
Ful often he seid alas and welawey
Lord crist qdhe hou may this world endur̉er/re
O ful of synne is many a Creature
O mighti god if that it be thy wille
Sith thou art rightful Iuge how may it be
Þat thou wilt suffre innocentis to spille

l.hi: And wickid folk reigne in prosperite

div.l: O good Constaunce alas so wo is me
ÞatI must be thi tormentour̉er/re or deye
On shames deþe ther̉er/re is none oþ̉er/re wey
Thei wepen bothyong and olde in al þᵉ place
Went that the king this lettir hadde sent
And Constaunce wᵗith a dedely pale face
Þe fourth day toward hir ship she went
But natheles she takith wᵗith good intent
Þe wille of crist and knelith on þe strond
She seid lord ay welcum thi sond
He thatme kept from the fals blame
Whils that I was on the lond among you
He can me kepe from harm ⁊and eke fro shame
In the salt see al þough I se not how
As strong as euer hewas he is rightnow
In him trust I and in his modir dere
Þatis to me my saile and eke my ster̉er/re
Hir litle child lay weping in hir Arme
And kneling pitousli to him she seid
Peas litle sonne I wil do þee non harm
Wᵗith that the coủer/rechif of hir hede she breid
And ouer̉er/re his litil iyen she it leid
And in hir arme she lullid itful fast
And into heuen hir iyen up she cast
Modir qd she and maiden bright marye
Soth isthatthurgh womans egment
Mankinde was lorn ⁊and dampned ay to dye
For which thi child was on a cros y rent
Thi blisful iyen saw alle this torment
Than is ther̉er/re no comparisoıı̄un bitwene
Thi wo and my wo þat any man mai sustene
Thou saw thy child slayn bifor̉er/re thyn iyen
And yit now lyueth my litil child perfay
Now ladi bright to whom al woful crien
Thou glorye of womanhode þou feir may
Thou hauen of refute bright sterre of day
Rue on my child that of thi gentilnesse
Ruest on euery sinfulle in distresse
O litil child alas what is thi gilt
Þat neuer wroughtist synne as yit ꝑper/parde
Whi wil thine hard fadir haue þe spilt
O mercy dere Constable coth she
As lat my litil child duelle here wᵗith þee
And if thou dar not saue him fro blame
So kisse him ones in his fadirs name
Therwithshe lokithbakward to þe lond
And seid farwel husbond routhelesse
And up she risith and walkith doun þᵉ strond
Toward the shippe hir folowed al þe prees
And eủer/re she praieth hir child to hold his pees
And takith hir leve wᵗith an hool intent
She blissith hir and into shippe shewent
Y vitaild was the shipp itwas no drede
Habundantli for hir ful long space
And othir necessaries þat shuld nede
She had ynough thankid be goddis grace
For winde and wedir almighti god pchace
And bring hir home I can no bettir seye
But in the see she driueth furþ hir weye
Alla the king comethhome sone aftir this
Vnto this castel of which I tolde
And axith where his wif and his child is
The Constable gan about his hert cold
And plainli al the matier he him told
As ye haıı herd I can telle it no bettir
And shewid the kyng his seal ⁊and eke his lre
And seid lord as ye comaundid me
Vp peyn of deth so haue I done certeyn
This messanger̉er/re tormentid was till he
Must beknow and told platte and plain
From night to night in what place he had leyn
And thus bi witte and sotell enquering
Ymagend was bi whom þis harm gan spng /
The hand was known þat the lre wrote
And al the venem of this cursid dede
But in what wise certeinli I note
Theffect is this / that Alla out of drede
His modir slough / þᵗat men mai plainli rede
For that she traitour was to hir liegeaunce
Thus endith olde Doinegild wᵗith myschaunce
¶ The sorow that this Alla night and day
Makith for his wif and his child also
Ther̉er/re nys no tunge that it telle may
But now wille I vnto Constaunce go
That fletith in the see in peyn and wo
V yere and more as likith cristis sond
Or that hir shippe approchith to þe lond
Vndir an hethen castelle atthe laste
Of which the name in my text I not finde
Constaunce and eke hir child þe See upcast
Almighti god that saueth al mankinde
Haue on Constaunce ⁊and on hir child sum mynde
Þat fallen was in hethen hand eft sone
In point to spille as I shal tell you sone
Doun fro the castel cometh þ̉er/re many a wight
To gaure on this shippe and on Constaunce
But shortly from the castel on a night
Þe lordis stuward god yeue him mischaunce
A thefe that had renayed oure creaunce
Cam into shippe allone and seid she shuld
His leman be wheþir she wold or nold
Tho was this wrechid woman wo begon
Hir child cryed and she cried pitously
But blisful mary halp hir right anon
For wᵗith hir struggling wel and mightily
The theef felle ouer the boord al sodenly
And in the see he dreint for vengeaıı̄unce
And thus hath crist vnwemmed kept cōmstāmce
O foul lust of luxurie lo thine ende
Not onli for thou feintist mannes mynde
But veraili thou wilt his bodi shende
Þe ende of thi werk or of thi lustis blinde
In complainyng hou many mai men finde
Þat not for werk sumtime but for þentent
To do this synne ben eiþir slain or shent
Furth goth hir Shipp thurgh þe narow mouþe
Of Iubaltar and Sept dryuyng ay
Sumtime west and sumtime norþ ⁊and south
And sumtime est ful many a sorye day
Til cristis modir y blissid be she ay
Hath shapen thurgh hir endles goodnesse
To make an ende of alle hir heuynesse
¶ Now lat vs stint of Constaunce but a þrow
And speke we of the Romain Emperour̉er/re
And out of Surry hath bi lres knowe
Þe slaughtir of cristen folk ⁊and dishonour̉er/re
Done to his doughtir by a fals traytour̉er/re
I mene the cursid wickid Soudanesse
Þat atte fest lete sle bothe more ⁊and lesse
For which this Emꝑper/parour̉er/re hath sent anon
His Senatoure with riall ordinaunce
And othir lordis god woot many one
On Surriens to taken his vengeaunce
Þey brenne sle and bring hem to mischᵃunce
Ful many a day but shortly this is þe ende
Homward to Rome they shape hem to wend
This Senatour̉er/re repairith with victory
To Romeward sailing fulle royally
And mette the shippe driuyng as seiþ þᵉ story
In which Constaunce sitte fulle pitously
No thing knew he what shewas newhy
She was in such aray / ne she wold seye
Of hir astate though þatshe shuld deye
He bringith hir to Rome and to his wif
He yaue hir and to his yong sonne also
And with the Senatour she ledde hir lif
Thus can oure ladi bring oute of woo
Woful Constaunce and many anoþ̉er/re moo
And longtime duellid in that place
In holi werkis euer̉er/re as was hir grace
The Senatours wif hir Awnte was
But for al that she knew hir neủer/re þᵉ mor̉er/re
I nylle no lenger̉er/re tary in this case
Butto king Alla which I spak of yore
That for his wif wepith and sighith sore
I wil returne and lete I wil constce
Vndir the Senatoures gouernaunce
¶ Kyng Alla which þᵗathad his mod slayn
Vpon a day felle in such Repentaunce
That if I shortli telle shalle and plaine
To Rome he cometh to receyue his penᵃnce
And putte him the popis ordinaunce
In high and lowe and ihu crist besought
Forgeue his wikid werkis þᵗathe wrought
The fame anon thurgh the tovn is born
Hou Alla king shal come on pilgremage
By herbegeours thatwenthim beforn
For which the Senatour̉er/re as wasvsage
Rood him ageyn / ⁊and many of his linage
As wel to shew his high magnificence
As to do any thing of Reuerence
Grete chere doth this noble Senatour̉er/re
Vnto king Alla and he to him also
Eithir of hem doth othir gret honour̉er/re
And so bifel on a day aftir or two
This Senatour is to king Alla y go
To feest / and shortli if I shal not lye
Constaunce sonne went in his cıı̄unpany
Summen wold sey at request of cōmstance
This Senatour had lad þis child to fest
I mai not telle euery Circumstaunce
Be as be may ther̉er/re was he at leest
But soth it is right athis modirs hest
Beforn Alla during the mete space
Þe child stood loking in the kingis face
This Alla king hath of þˢ child gret wondir
And to the Senatour he seid anon
Whos is þat feir̉er/re child þat stondiþ yond
I note coth he bi god and bi seint Iohn
A modir he hath butfadir hath he none
Þat I ofwoot / but shortly in a stounde
He told alla hou thatthe child was found
But god woot quod this Senatour̉er/re also
So vertuous a lyver in alle my life
Ne saw I neủer/re as she ne here of moo
Of worldli women maiden ne ofwif
I dar wel sey she had wel leuer a knife
Þurgh hir brest þan be a woman wicke
Þer is no man couth bring hir to þᵗat pricke
Now was this child as like vnto Constaunce
As possible is a Creature forto be
This Alla hath the face in remembᵃunce
Of dame Constaunce ⁊and therof musid he
If thatthe childis modir were aught she
That was his wife / ⁊and pryueli he sight
And spedde him fro þe table þᵗathe might
Parfay thought he fantoıı̄un is myn hede
I ought deme of rightful Iugement
Þat in the salt See my wif is dede
And aftirward he made his Argument
Whatwoot I if that crist had hidir sent
My wif bi see as wel as he hir sent
To my cuntree fro thens that she went
And aftir none home with the Senatour̉er/re
Goth Alla forto see this wondir chaunce
This Senatour̉er/re doth Alla gret honour̉er/re
And hastili he sent aftir Constaunce
But trustith wel hir list not forto daunce
Whan that she wistwherfor̉er/re was þᵗat sond
Vnneth on hir fete might she stonde
Whan Alla saw his wif feir̉er/re he hir grett /
And wept thatitwas routh to see
For at first look he on hir̉er/re sette
He knew wel veraili þat it was she
And she for sorow as dombe stant as a tre
So was hir hert shet in hir Distresse
Whan she remembird his vnkindenesse
Twise she swoned in his ovne sight
He wept and him excusid pitously
Now god coth he and his halows briȝt
So wisli on my soule as haue mercy
That of your harme as giltles am I
As is maurice my sonne so like yỏer/re face
Els the fendme fecche out of þis place
Long was the suobbing and bittir peyne
Or that þeir̉er/re woful hertis myght cese
Gret was the pite forto here hem pleyne
Thurgh which pleintꝭes gan þ̉er/re wo encrece
I pray you al my labour to Relece
I may not telle þeir wo vntil to morow
I am so wery forto speken of sorowe

Þe Shipmans tale
A mchaıı̄unt whilom duelt at seint Denyse
Þᵗat rich was for which men held him wise
A wif he hadde of excellent beaute
And cumpaynable and reuerent was she
Which is a thing that causith more dispence
Than worth is alle the chere ⁊and reuerence
That men hem done at festis ⁊and at daunces
Such salutacions and countenaunces
Passen as doth the shadou of a walle
But wo is him þat pay mot for alle
The celi husbond algat he mot pay
He mot vs cloth and also vs array
Al for his own worship richely
In which array we dauncen iolily
And if that he mai not ꝑper/parauenture
Or ellis list not such dispence endur̉er/re
But thinkith that it is wast ⁊and lost
Then mot another pai for our̉er/re cost
Or lene vs gold ⁊and that is ꝑper/parilous
¶This noble mchᵃunt held a noble hous
For which he had al dai gret repeyr̉er/re
For his larges and for his wif was feir
Þat wonder is / but herkneþ to my tale
Among al his gestis gret and smale
Þer̉er/re was a monk a feir̉er/re man ⁊and a bold
I trow .xxx.ᵗⁱ winter̉er/re he was olde
Þat eủer/re in one was drawing to þᵗat place
Þis yong monk that was so feir of face
Aqueintid was so wᵗith þat good man
And eke þis monk of which I began
Wer̉er/re both two y born in one village
The monk him claymed as for cosinage
And he agein seith not ones nay
But was as glad þ̉er/reof as foule of day
For to his hert it was a gret plesaunce
Þus ben þei knitt wᵗith etern alliaunce
And eche of hem gan othir̉er/re assure
Of brothirhede while þᵗat their̉er/re lif may dure
Free was dan Iohn ⁊and maineli of dispence
As in that hous and fulle of Diligence
To do plesaunce ⁊and also gret costage
He not forgat to yeue the lest page
In al þat hous / but aft̉er/re his degre
He yave the lord ⁊and siþen his meyne
Whan þat he cam sum man honest þing
For which þei were as glad of hˢ coming
As foul is fain when þe sonne vprisith
No more her̉er/re of as now for it sufficeth
But so befel þis mchaunt vpon a day
Shape him to make redi his array
Toward the toun of Brugis forto far̉er/re
To byen him there a porciou of ware
For which he hath to paris sent anon
A messanger̉er/re and þreid hath dan Iohn
Þat he shuld some to seint denys to pley
Wᵗith him and his wif a dai or twey
Or he to Brugis went in alle wise
This noble monk of which I you deuise
Hath of his abbot as him list licence
Because he was a man of high pᵘdence
And eke an officer out forto ryde
To sene her graungis ⁊and her barnes wide
And vnto seint denis he comeþ anoıı̄un
Who was so welcum as my lord dan Ion
Oure dere cosin fulle of curtesy
Wᵗith him brought a Iubbe of maluesy
⁊and eke anoþir ful of fine vernage
And volatile as ay was his vsage
⁊and thus I let hem ete ⁊and drink ⁊and pley
Þis mchaunt ⁊and þis monk a dai or tuey
The third dai this mchaunt up arisiþ
⁊and on his nede sadli him avisith
⁊and vp into his Countir hous goþ he
To reken wᵗith himselue as wele mai be
Of that yere hou that it wᵗith hym stode
And hou he / dispendid hadde his good
And if that he encresid were or none
His bokis and his baggis mani one
He leith aforn him on his countingbord
Ful riche was his tresour ⁊and his horde
For which ful fast his count̉er/re dore he shet
⁊and eke he nold þat noman shuld him let
Of his accomptꝭes for the mene time
⁊and thus he sitte til it was past prime
Dan Ion was risen in the morou also
⁊and in the garden walked too and fro
⁊and hath his thingis seid ful curteisli
This good wif cam walking pⁱriuely
Into the garden ther̉er/re he walkid soft
⁊and him salueþ as she hath done oft

Which as hir list she mai goủer/rene ⁊and gye
For yit vndir þe yerd was þe mayde
O . dere cosin myn dan Ion she sayd
What eilith you so rathe forto rise
Nece coth he it aught ynow suffice
.V. houres to slepe upon a nyght
But it were for an olde palled wiȝt
As ben thes weddid men þᵗat lyen ⁊and dare
As in a foorme sitte a wery hare
Were al forsteraught wᵗith houndis gt ⁊and smale
But Dere nece whi be ye so pale
I trow certis that oure godeman
Has you labourd sith the night began
Þat you were nede to resten hastily
⁊and wᵗith that word he lough ful merily
⁊and of his ovn thoughtis he wex al rede
This feire wif gan to shake hir hede
⁊and seid thus ye god wote alle coth she
Nai cosin myn it stant not so wᵗith me
For bi þat god þat yaue me soule ⁊and lif
In al the Reme of Fraunce is þ̉er/re no wif
Þat lesse lust hath to that sory pleye
For I mai sing alas and weleawey
Þat I . was borne but to no wight ꝙquod she
I . dar dat not telle hough it stant wᵗith me
Wherfore I think out of þis lond to wend
Or ellis of myselue to make an ende
So ful I . am of drede ⁊and eke of care

⁊and seid alas my nece god forbede
Þat ye for eny sorou or eny drede
Fordo yourselue but tellith me yoᵘur gref
ꝐPer/Parauenture I mai in youre myschef
Counceil or helpe ⁊and therfor telliþ me
Al your̉er/re avice for it shal be secree

Þat neủer/re in my list for lefe not loþe
Ne shal I . of no counceil you bewrey

Not for no cosinage ne alliaunce

⁊and eche of hem told oþ̉er/re what him list

Þan is the lefe þat hangis an þe tre

To haue the more cause of acqueintauce

⁊and hastith you ⁊and go your̉er/re weye anou
My dere loue seþ she oo Dan Ion
Ful lefe me were this counceil to hide

Þat euer was sith the world beganne
But sith I . am a wif it sit not to me
To tel no wight of oure priuitee
Neiþer in bedde ne in none oþir̉er/re place
God shield I . shuld tel it for his grace
A wif ne shul not sey of hir husbond
But al honour̉er/re as I can vndirstond
Saue vnto you thus moche tel I . shalle
As helpe me god he is nought worþ at all

⁊and wel ye wote þat women naturalli
Desiryn thingis . vj . as wele as . I .

Hardi ⁊and riche wise and ther̉er/re to free
⁊and buxum to his wif ⁊and fressh abedde

⁊and if myn husbond it might aspye

Þat you list in any maner̉er/re wise

Now truly myne owne ladi dere
