Sithen it may not amendid be
Wif he seid I . foryeue it thee
But bi your̉er/re lif be no more so large
Kepe bettir̉er/re my good þˢ yeve I . you charge
Thus endith my tale ⁊and god vs send
Tailing ynough vnto oure lyues end
WEl seid bi corpus dus ꝙquod our̉er/re host
Now long mot þou sail bi þe cost
Sir gentil maistir̉er/re gentil Marynere
God yeve the monk a . Mv . quade yere
Y felowes bewar̉er/re of such a iape
Þe monk put in þe mannes hode an ape
⁊and in his wivis also be seint austin
Drawiþ no monkis no more vnto yoᵘur yn
But now pas ouer̉er/re ⁊and lat vs seche about
Who shal now tel first of al this rout
Anoþir tale / ⁊and wᵗith that word he said
As curteisly as it had ben a maid
My ladi priores bi your̉er/re leve
So that I . wist I . shuld you not greve
I wold demen that ye telle shold
A tale next if so were that ye wold
Now wil ye vouchsauf my ladi dere
Gladly coth she and seid as ye shul her̉er/re

l.hi: Here endith the prolog of the pⁱrioresse
And the tale folowiþ on þat oþir syde

div.l: GOd our̉er/re lord thi name hough muelous
In this large world is spredde ꝙquod she
For not onli thy lawe Preciouse
Parfourmed is by men of dignite
But bi the mouth of childirn þi bounte
Parfourmed is / for on þe brest souking
Sumtime thee preine in thyne heryng
Wherfore in laude as I best can or may
Of thee and of the lily floure
Which thee bare ⁊and is a maid alway
To tel a storie I wil do my labour̉er/re
Nought þat I mai encrece hir honoᵘur
For she hirselue is honour̉er/re ⁊and þe rote
Of bounte next hir son ⁊and soules bote
O . modir ⁊and maide . O . maid ⁊and modir fre
O . bussh vnbrent brennyng in moyses siȝt
That ravishidist doun from the Deitee
Thurgh þine humblenes þe gost in þee liȝt
Of whos v̉er/retue when he thine hert dight
Conceyued was the fadirs sapience
Help me to tell it in thy Reuerence
Ladi thi bounte and thy magnificence
Thi vertu and thi gret humilite
Ther may no tong expsse þine innocēmce
For sumtime ladi or men pray to þee
Thou gost beforn of thi benyngnite
And getist vs the light of thi prayer̉er/re
To giden vs to thy sonne so Dere
My connyng is so weyk O . blissfull quene
Forto declare thy gret worthynesse
Þat I . ne may the weight sustene
But as a child of xij. month or lesse
That can vnneth eny word expresse
Right so fare I ⁊and therfore I you preye
Gideth my song ⁊and I shalle of you seye
Ther was in Assy in a grete Citee
Amonges cristen peple . a . Iurye
Susteyned bi a lord of that cuntre
For foule vsure ⁊and lucre of vilany
Hateful to crist ⁊and to his cumpany
⁊and þurgh the strete men miȝt ride ⁊and wēmd
For it was fre ⁊and open at euery ende
A litle scole of cristen folk ther̉er/re stode
Doun at furþer̉er/re ende in which þ̉er/re wer̉er/re
Cristen childir̉er/re of worshipfull blode
Þat lerned in that scole yere bi yere
Such man doctrine as men vsid þer̉er/re
Þis is to seye to sing and to rede
As smale childir done in her chidhede
Among thes children was a widow son
A . litle clergeoıı̄un of vij . yere of age
Þat dai be dai to scole was he woıı̄un
⁊and eke also where as he saw þe ymage
Of cristis modir he hadde in vsage
As him was taught to knele adoun ⁊and sei
As he goth his aue marie by the wey
Thus hath this widow hir litle son taught
Oure blissid ladi cristis modir Dere
To worship ay ⁊and he forgat it nought
For celi child wil alwei sone lere
But euer when I remembre on þˢ mater̉er/re
Seint Nicholas stant eủer/re in my presence
For he so yong to crist didde reuerence
This litle child his litle book lernyng
As he sate in the scole at his prymere
He alma redemptoris herde syng
As childirn lerned their̉er/re antiphoner̉er/re
⁊and as he durst he drue him nere ⁊and nere
And herkned ay the wordis ⁊and þe note
Til he the first vers coude al be rote
Nought wist he what þˢ latine was to sey
For he so yong was and tendir̉er/re of age
But on a day his felow gan he prey
To expoun him þis song in his langage
Or tel him whi this song was in vsage
Thus preid he him to construe ⁊and declare
Ful oft time upon his knees bare
His felow which than elder was þan he
Answerd him thus þis song I . haue herd sei
Was made of oure blissid ladi free
Hir to salue and also forto prey
To be oure help ⁊and socour̉er/re when we dey
I . can no more expoun in þis matier̉er/re
I . lern song I . can but small gramer̉er/re
And is this song made in the reủer/reence
Of cristis modir seid this Innocent
Now certes I wil do my diligence
To konne it alle or cristmas be went
Þough þat I . for my pⁱrimer shal be shent
⁊and be bete thries withyn an honour̉er/re
I . wil it konne oure lady to honour̉er/re
His felow taught him homward pⁱriuely
From dai to day til he coude be rote
⁊and than he sang it alle boldilye
Fro word to word acording with the note
Twyes a day it past thurgh his throte
To scoleward ⁊and homward when he went
On cristis modir sette was his entent
As I haue seid thorout the Iury
Þis litil child as he com to ⁊and fro
Ful merili wold he sing and cry
O . alma redemptoris euermoo
The swetnesse his hert ꝑper/parcid so
Of cristis modir þat to hir to py
He can not stint going bi the wey
Our̉er/re first fo the serpent Sathanas
Þat hath in the Iuwes hert hˢ waspˢ nest
Vp swal and seid . oo . ebreik peple alas
Is this a thing to you that is honest
Þat such a boy shal walken as him lest
In your̉er/re despite ⁊and sing of such sentence
Which is ayens your̉er/re lawes reuerence
Fro thensfurth the Iuwes haue conspired
This Innocent out of this world to chase
An homicide therto han thei hired
Þat in an aley hadde a pryuee place
And as the child gan forby to pas
Þis cursid Iuwe him hent ⁊and held him fast
⁊and cut his throte ⁊and in a pitt him cast
I sei that in a wardrop thei him thrue
Where as the Iuwes purgen her̉er/re entrayle
O. cursid folk of heroudes alle newe
What mai your ill entent you avayle
Mordir̉er/re wil out certen it wil not fail
⁊and nameli ther̉er/re as the honoᵘur of god shal fail
Þe blode out cryeth of youre cursid dede
O martir̉er/re offendid vnto virginite
Now maistow sing folowing eủer/re in one
The white lambe celestial coth she
Of which the gret euᵃngelist seint Iohn
In pathmose wrote which seiþ þei gan gon
Beforn this lambe ⁊and sing a song all newe
Þat neủer/re flesshli woman they ne knewe
This pore wedow awaiting all þᵗat night
Aftir hir litil childe but he come nought
For which as sone as it was day light
Wᵗith face pale of drede and bisy thought
She hath at scole ⁊and ellis where him souȝt
Til finally she gan so ferre aspye
That he last was sene in the Iury
¶ Wᵗith modirs pite wᵗithyn hir̉er/re brest enclosed
She goth as she were out of hir̉er/re mynde
To euery place where as she supposed
Bi liklyhode hir̉er/re litil finde to fynde
And euer on cristis modir meke ⁊and kinde
She cried / ⁊and at lat thus she wrought
Among the cursid Iwes she him sought
She frayneth and she prayeth pitously
To euery Iuwe that duelliþ in þat place
To telle hir if hir child went forth by
Thei seiden nay . but ihu of his grace
Yaf in hir thought wᵗithyn a litle space
Þat in that place aftir̉er/re hir son she cride
Where he was cast in a pitte beside
O gret god that ꝑper/parfourmest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentis lo her̉er/re þi miȝt
This gemme of chastite this Emeraude
⁊and also of martirdom the Rubye bright
Ther he wᵗith throte y corve lay vpright
He alma redemptoris beganne to syng
So loude þat al the place began to ryng
The cristen folk that þurgh þe strete wet
In com forto wondre upon this thing
And hastili thei for the ꝓprouost sent
He com anou wᵗith out eny tarying
⁊and herieth crist that is oure heuen king
⁊and also his modir̉er/re honour̉er/re of al mankynde
⁊and . aft̉er/re the Iues lete he bynde
This child with pitous lamentacon
Vp taken was singing his song alwey
And wᵗith honour̉er/re and grete ꝓprocessiou
Thei cary vnto the next Abbeye
His swonyng modir bi his bere lay
Vnneth might the peple þat was þer̉er/re
This yong Rachel bring from his bere
Wᵗith torment ⁊and wᵗith shenfull deth echon
This ꝓprouost doth the Iues forto sterve
That of this mordre wist ⁊and þᵗat anou
He wold no such cursidnesse obserue
Evil thei shul haue that euel deʆser/sirue
Þ̉er/refore wᵗith wilde hors he didde hem draw
And aftir that did hang hem bi the law
Vpon this bere lith this Innocent
Beforn the chefe auter̉er/re while þᵉ masse last
And aftir that thabbot wᵗith his couent
Haue sped hem forto bery him ful fast
⁊and . then thei haly watir̉er/re on him cast
⁊and . yit when cast was the haly wat̉er/re
The childe song alma Redemptoris mat̉er/re.
This Abbot which that was an holy man
As monkes ben or ellis ought forto be
This yong childe conIure beganne
And seid . oo . dere childe I hals thee
In vertue of the holy Trinite
Tel me what is thi cause forto sing
Sith that thi throte is cutte to my semyg
My throte is cutte vnto my nek bone
Seid this child / and as by wey of kynde
I . shuld a dyed long tyme a gone
But ihu crist as ye in bokes fynde
Wil that his glory last ⁊and be in mynde
And for worship of his modir dere
Yit may I sing . O alma bright ⁊and cler̉er/re
This welle of mcy cristis modir̉er/re swete
I . loued alwey as aftir̉er/re my connyng
⁊and when that I . my lif shuld forlete
To me she com ⁊and bad me to syng
Þis antym which in my dying
As ye han herd what I. haue song
Me thought she leid a greyn on my tong
Therfore I . sing ⁊and sing mot certeyn
In honour of that blissid maiden free
Til fro my tong be taken awey þe greyn
And aftir this seid she to me
My litil child now wil I . fecch thee
When the greyn is fro thi tong y take
Be not agast I . nyl thee not forsake
This holy monk this abbot him mene I .
His tong out caught ⁊and toke awey þe greyn
And he yave up the gost fulle softely
And when þabbot had þis wondir seyn
His salt teeris tricled doun as Reyn
And groflyng he fell flat upon þᵉ gᵒund
And stille he lay as he had ben bound
The Covent also lay doun on þe pavemet
Weping and herying cristis modir dere
⁊and aftir that they risen ⁊and furþ þey went
⁊and . toke awey this mart̉er/re from his bere
⁊and . in a Tumbe of marble stones clere
Enclosid they his litle body swete
There he is now god gᵃunt vs to mete
¶ O yong hugh of lincolne . also
With cursid Iuwes as it is notable
For it is but a litle while ago
Pray eke for vs we sinful folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so merciable
On vs his gret mercy multiplye
For reuerence of his modir mary

l.hi: The ꝓprolog of Chauc̉er/res tale of ʆser/sir Thopas

div.l: When endid was þˢ miracle eủer/rey man
Al sobre were wondir it was to se
Till oure host Iape thoo beganne
⁊and then at last he lokid upon me
⁊and seid thus what man artow ꝙquod he
Thou lokest as thou wold finde an hare
For eủer/re vpon the grounde I . se þe stare
Approche nere and loke vp merily
War you sir ⁊and lat þis man haue place
He in the wast is shapen as wel as I .
Þis were a . puppet in armes to enbrace
For eny woman small ⁊and feir of face
He semeth eluyssh as bi his countenaunce
For vnto no wight doth he Daliaunce
Sey now sumwhat sith othir folk han seid
Telle vs a . tale of mirth ⁊and that anon
Host coth I . ne beth not euel appaid
For othir tale certis can I . none
But of a Ryme I . lerned long agon
Ye that is good ꝙquod he shul we it here
Sum deyntee þing me þink bi thi cher
Listneth lordis in good entent
And I . wil telle verament
Of miracle and of Solas
All of a knight was feir̉er/re ⁊and gent
In batail and tornement
His name was sir Thopas
Y . born he was in ferre cuntre
In flaundirs alle beyond the See
At popering in the place
His fadir was man ful fre
And lord he was of that cuntre
As it was goddis grace
Sir Thopas was a douȝti sweyn
White was his face as payndmayn
His lippis rede as Rose
His rudde is like scarlet in greyn
I . you telle in good certeyne
He hadde a semely nose
His here his berd like saffrou
That to his girdle raught adoun
His shone of fine cordewane
Of Brugis was his hosen broun
His Roob was of Sicladoun
It cost ful many a Iane
He couth hunt at wilde dere
⁊and ride on hunting to the Ryuer̉er/re
Wᵗith grey goshaukes on hond
Therto he was A good Archere
To wrastle was ther̉er/re non his per̉er/re
Ther̉er/re eny man shuld stond
Ful many a maide bright in bour̉er/re
They mourn for him ꝑper/paramour̉er/re
When thei lette to slepe
But he was chast ⁊and no lechour̉er/re
⁊and swete as is the bramble flour̉er/re
That berith the rede hepe
¶ And so befel vpon a day
Forsoth as . I . you telle may
Sir Thopas wolde out ryde
He worth vpon his stede gray
And in his hond a launcegay
A . long swerde by his side
He prikith thurgh a feir̉er/re forest
Þ̉er/re in is many a wilde Best
Ye bothe Bukke and hare
And as he prikith north ⁊and est
I . tell you he hadde almest
Betidde a sory Care
Ther̉er/re spⁱringen erbis gret ⁊and smale
The licorice and the Sete wale
And many a clove Ielofre
And notemuges to putte in ale
Wheþir it be moyst or stale
Or forto leyen in Cofre
The birdis singen it is no nay
The sper̉er/re hauke ⁊and the popingay
That ioye it was to here
The Thurstilcok made eke hˢ lay
The wodecok vpon the Spray
She sang fulle lowde and clere
Sir Thopas fill in loue longyng
When he herd the thurstle syng
He priked As he were wode
His feir̉er/re stede in his prikyng
So swette þᵗat men might him wring
His Sides were alle blood
Sir Thopas eke so wery was
For pⁱriking on the soft grasse
So fers was his courage
That doun he leid him in þᵗat plas
To make his Stede sum solace
For he was so Sauage
O . seint marie benedicite
What ayles this loue at me
To binde me so sore
Me dremed all this night ꝑper/parde
An elf quene wil my leman be
And slepe vndir my gore
An elf quene wil I . loue y wis
For in this world no woman is
Worthy to be my make /
¶ In tovn
Alle women I forsake
⁊and to an elf quene I me betake
By dales and eke by downe
Into his sadil he cam anou
He prikith ouer stile ⁊and stone
An elf quene to aspye
Till he so long hath riden ⁊and gon
That he founde in a pⁱrivee wone
The Cuntree of Feyrie
To him come a ioly geant
His name was cleped ʆser/sir Olifant
A . perilous man in dede
He seid Child by Termagaut
But if thou prik out of myn haut
Anone I slee thy Stede
¶ Wᵗith mace
Here is the Quene of Feirye
With harpe pipe and Simphony
Duellyng in this Place
The Child seid so mot I . thee
To morow will I . mete thee
When I . haue myn armour̉er/re
And yit I . hoop par ma fay
That thou shalt wᵗith this lancegay
Abye it fulle Soure
I . shall perce if I . may
Or it be fulli prime of day
For here I . shalle the slaw
Sir Thopas drue a bak fast
This geant at him stones cast
Out of a staffe Slyng
But feire ascapith sir Thopas
And al was thurgh goddis gᵃce
And his feyre beryng
Yit listneþ lordingꝭes to my tale
Meryer̉er/re then the nyghtyngale
For now . I . wille you Rowne
How Sir Thopas wᵗith sidis smale
Priking ouer downe and Dale
Is com ageyne to Towne
His mery man comaundid he
To make him both game ⁊and gle
For nedis he must fight
With a geant with hedis thre
For paramour̉er/re and Iolitee
Of one that shone fulle bright
Do com he seid my minstrales
And Iesters forto tell vs tales
Anou in myne Armyng
Of Romances that ben riales
Of popes and of Cardinals
And eke of loue likyng
They fette him first the swete wine
⁊and methe eke in massaline
And Royall Spicerye
Of gyngirbrede that was so fyne
And licorice and eke Comyne
And Sugre that was trye
He didde next his whatlere
Of clothe of lake fine ⁊and clere
A Breche and eke a Shert
And next his Shert an actou
And ovir̉er/re that an haubergeou
For percing of his hert
Aboven that a . fine hauberk
Was all wrought of Iewis werk
Ful strong it was of Plate
And oủer/re that his Cote Armour̉er/re
As white as is . a . lili floure
In which he wille Debate
His Shield was alle of gold so rede
And theryn was a Bores hede
A Charbocle beside
⁊and. there he swore on ale ⁊and brede
Hough that the geant shuld be dede
Betide what so betyde
His Iambiaux was of querboily
His Swerdis shethe of yvorye
His helm of laton bright
His Sadil was of Ruell bone
His Bridil as the Sonne it shone
Or as the Mone light
His Spere was of fine Sipres
That bodith werre ⁊and nothing pes
The hede ful sharp was grounde
His stede was alle dapul grey
It goth and amble by the weye
Fulle softly and fulle rounde
Lo lordingꝭes here is a Fitte
If ye wil eny more of it
To telle it wille I found
Now hold your̉er/re tong for charite
Both knight and alle peple free
And herkneth to my Spelle
Of bataile and of Cheualrye
And of ladies loue drury
Anone I wille you telle
Men speken of tormentꝭes of Ire
Of hornchild and of ypotice
Of Bevice and Sir Guye
Of sir libous and Pleyndemoᵘur
But sir Thopas berith the floᵘur
Of alle Cheualrye
His good Stede he bestrede
And furth his weye he rode
As spacle out of Brond
Vpon his Crest he bare a tour̉er/re
And theryn stiked a lily flour̉er/re
God shield his corps fro shond
And for he was knght aventro9
He ne slept in none house
But logid in his hode
His bright helm was his wonger̉er/re
And bi him baited his Destrer̉er/re
Of erbis fyne and good
Himselue drank watir̉er/re of þᵉ well
As didde the knight ʆser/sir ꝑper/parcyuell
So worthy vndir wede .
¶ No more of this for goddis dyntee
Coth oure host for þou makist me
So wery of thy v̉er/reay lewdenesse
That al so wisly god my soule blesse
Myn eris aken of thi drasti speche
But such arime the deuel I . beteche
This may wel be rime dogrel qd he
Why so coth I . why wiltow lett me
More of my tale then anothir̉er/re man
Sith that it is the best ryme that I . can
Be god qd he for pleinly at one word
Thi drasty rime is not worth one tord
Thou dost not ellis but dispendist time
Sir at one word þou shalt no leng ryme
Lat se whethir̉er/re thou can tell ought in gest
Or tell sumwhat in prose at lest
In which ther̉er/re may be sum mirth or doctⁱne
Gladli qd I . be goddis swete pyne
I . wil you tel a litil thing in prose
That aught to like you as . I . suppose
Or ellis certis ye ben to daungero9
For it is a moral tale vertuous
Albe it told sumtime in sundri wise
Of sundry folk as I . shal you deuise
Al thus ye wote that eủer/rey Euᵃngelist
That tellith vs the peyn of ihu crist
Ne seith not all thing as his felow doþ
But naþeles yit is their sentence soth
⁊and alle accorden as in their̉er/re sentence
Albe þer̉er/re in their̉er/re telling Difference
For sum of hem sey more ⁊and sum lesse
When thei his pitous passioıı̄un expresse
I . mene of Marc Mathue like ⁊and Iohn
But doutlesse their̉er/re sentence is al but one
Therfore lordingꝭes all I . you beseche
If that you think I vary in my speche
As thus / if that I . telle sumwhat more
Of ꝓprouerbis / then ye han herd before
Comphendid in this litle tretice here
To enforce wᵗith theffect of my matere
⁊and though I . not the same wordis seye
As ye han herd yit to you all I . prey
Blameth me not for as in my sentence
Shul ye fynden no Difference
Fro the sentence of this tretice lite
Aftir . which this mery tale I write
And therfore herkneth what that I . sey
⁊and lat me telle alle my tale I you prey
¶ Here endith Chaucers tale of sir Thopas
A doughty knight in alle his dede .
God help vs and seint Thomas
⁊and gᵃunt vs alle grace wele to spede

ab.hi: The tale of Melibeus and prudens

div.ab:
Vpon a day it befell þat
for his disport he went into the feldis him to pley

His wif ⁊and eke his dought̉er/re he left wᵗithin his hous of
which the dores were fast y shett

And thre of his
olde foen haue aspied it ⁊and setten ladders to the
wallis of his hous / ⁊and bi the wondowes ben they
entrid

⁊and beten his wif ⁊and woundid his dought̉er/re wᵗith
. v . mortal woundis in v . sundry places /

And when Me=
libeus turned was into his hous ⁊and saw alle this
mischef . he like a madde man renting his cloþis
began to wepe ⁊and crye /

Prudence his wif as fer-
forth as she durst besoght him of his wepyng
forto stent /

But not for thy he gan to cry ⁊and wepe
eủer/re lenger̉er/re the mor̉er/re //

This noble wif prudens
remembird hir vpon the sentence of Ouyde in his
boke y clepid the Remedy of loue / wher̉er/re as he seiþ

he is a fole that disturbith the modir̉er/re to wepe for
the deþ of hir child / til she haue wept hir fill as
for a certeyn time /

⁊and then shal a man do his dili-
gence wᵗith amyable wordis hir to recumfort ⁊and pᵃy
hir to stint hir /weping

For which resou this
noble wif prudence suffred hir husbond forto wepe
⁊and cry for a c̉er/reteyn space /

div.l: Whēmn endid was the tale of melibee
And of prudence ⁊and hir benyngnite
Oure host seid as I am feiþful man
And bi þe precious corpus madrian
I . had leuer̉er/re then a barell ale
Þat good leef my wif had herd þˢ . tale
For she is no þing of such pacience
As was þis melibeus wif prudence
By cockis bones when I bete my knavis
She brynges me þe gret clubbid stavis /
And crieth sle the doggis enerichoıı̄un
And breke of hem boþe bakke ⁊and bone
And if þat eny neybour of myne
Wil not in church to my wif incline
Or be so hardi to hir̉er/re to trespace
When she comeþ home she rampiþ īm my face
And crieþ fals coward wreke thi wif
Bi corpus bones I . wil haue thi knyfe
And þou shat haue my distaf ⁊and go spyn
From dai to night þus she wil begynne
Alas she seiþ þat euer̉er/re I . was y shape
To wedde a milksop or so gret an ape
Þat wil be ouer ladde wᵗith euery wight
⁊and out at dore anone I . mot me dight
Or els I . am lost but if that I .
Be like a leoıı̄un fo wode leoıı̄un fole hardi
I . wote wel she wil do me sle sum day
Sum neibour̉er/re / ⁊and then go my way
For I am ꝑper/parilous wᵗith knife in hond .
Al be it that I . dar̉er/re not hir̉er/re withstond
For she is bigge in armes be my feiþ
Þat shal he finde þat to hir mys seiþ
But lat vs pas ouer of þis matere
My lord ʆser/sir monk he seiþ be mery of cher̉er/re
For ye shulle telle vs a tale truli
Lo Rouchestir stondiþ here fast by
Ride furþ myne own lord breke not oᵘur. game
But be my trouþ I . know not your name
Whedir I shal calle you my lord dan Ion
Or dan thomas or ellis dan alboıı̄un
Of what hous be ye bi your fadir kynne
I vow to god þou hast a . ful feire skyn
It is a . gentil pasture þer̉er/re thou gost
Thou art not like a . forpined gost
Vpon my feiþ þou art sum officer̉er/re
Sum worþi sexten or sum Celarer̉er/re
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Þou art maist̉er/re when þou art at home
No pore cloistrer̉er/re ne no pore novice
But gouernour ⁊and that wily ⁊and wise
And ther wᵗith all of brawnes ⁊and of bones
A wel feir̉er/re ꝑper/parsone for the nones
I . pray to god yeve him confucioıı̄un
Þat first þee brought into religioıı̄un
Þou woldist haue ben a tredefoul ariȝt
Haddistow as gret leve as þᵘ hast miȝt
To ꝑper/parfourme al thi lust in engendrur̉er/re
Thou haddist begoten mani a creatur̉er/re
Alas whi weristow so wide a coop
God yeue me sorou but ⁊and I wer̉er/re a pope
Not onli þou but eủer/rey mighty man
Þough he were shorn an hye upon þᵉ pan
Shuld haue a wif for al þis world is lorn
Religioıı̄un haþ taken up all the Corne
Of treding ⁊and we borell men be shrimpis
Of feble trees comeþ wrechid yinpis
Þis makiþ þat oure childir be so sclendir̉er/re
⁊and feble þat þei may not wele engendir̉er/re
Þis makiþ þat oure wivis wille assay
Religious folk for þei mai bettir̉er/re pay
Of venus payment þen may we
God wote no lusshborous pay ye
But be not wroþ my lord þough I play
Ful oft in game a soþe I . haue herd say
Þis worþi monk toke alle in pacience
⁊and seid I . wille do alle my Diligence
As ferre as soroueþ into honestee
To telle you a tale or two or thre
⁊and if you lust to herken hidirward
I . wil you seye the lif of seint Edward
Or els tragedis first wille I . telle
Of which I haue an . C . in my selle
Tragedis is forto telle a c̉er/reten storie
As olde bokes maken memorie
Of hem þat stode in gret ꝓprosperite
⁊and is y fallen out of high Degre
Into misery / ⁊and endith wrechidly
⁊and þei ben versified / comonly
Of vj . fete . þat men clepe exametroıı̄un
In prose eke ben endid many one
And eke of metre in mani sundrie wise
Lo þis ought you ynough suffice
Now herkenth if you lust forto her̉er/re
But first I . you beseche in þis mater̉er/re
Þough I bi ordre telle not þees thingꝭes
Be it of popes Emꝑper/parours or kingꝭes
⁊and aftir her age as men writen finde
But telle hem sum before ⁊and sum behinde
As it comeþ now vnto my remembᵃunce
Haue me excused of myne ignorance
I wil bewail in maner̉er/re of tᵃgedye
Þe harm of hem þat stode in hye degre
And fallen so þat ther̉er/re nas no remedie
To bring hem out of their̉er/re aduersite
For certen when fortune list to fle
Þer̉er/re mai no man þe cours of hir wᵗithhold
Lat no man trust on blinde ꝓprosperite
Beþ war̉er/re of þis ensample yong ⁊and old
At lucifer̉er/re though he an aungell were
⁊and not a man / at him I wille begynne
For þough fortune may none angel der̉er/re
From high degre yit fel he for his syn
Doun into helle where he is ynne
O . lucifer brightist of aungels all
Now artow sathanas þou maist not twyn
Out of misery in which þou art yfall
Also Adam in þe felde of Damascene
Wᵗith goddis ovne fingir wrought was he
⁊and not begoten of mannes sꝑper/parme vnclene
⁊and welt al paradis sauyng one Tree
⁊and neuer̉er/re worldli man had so high degre
As Adam had / til he for his goủer/renaunce
Was dryuen out of his high ꝓprosꝑper/parite
To labour̉er/re ⁊and to helle ⁊and to myschaunce
Lo Sampsoıı̄un which was annunciat
Bi the aungel long or his natiuite
⁊and was to god almighti consecrat
⁊and stode in noblesse whils he might se
Was neuer̉er/re such anoþir̉er/re as was he
To speke of strength ⁊and þ̉er/reto hardinesse
But to his wyues told he his secree
Þurgh which he slue himselue in wrechidnes
Sampson this noble ⁊and mighti Champioıı̄un
Wᵗithout wepen saue his hondes tweye
He slue and alto rent the Leoıı̄un
Toward his wedding walking bi þᵉ wey
His fals wif coude him so pleas ⁊and prey
Til she his counceil knew ⁊and she vntrue
Vnto his foos his counceil can bewrey
⁊and him forsoke ⁊and toke anothir̉er/re newe
An hundird foxes toke Sampson for ire
⁊and alle their̉er/re tailes he togidir bond
⁊and sette the foxis tailes alle on fire
For he in eueri taile had put a brond
⁊and þei brent al þe tovnes in the lond
⁊and al her Olyves ⁊and her vines eke
A . þousand men eke he slue wᵗith his hond
⁊and had no wepen but an asse cheke
When þei wer̉er/re slain so þirstid him þat he
Was welny lorne / for which he gan prey
Þat god wold of his mci haue sıı̄unm pite
⁊and send him drink or ellis must he deye
⁊and of þis asse cheke þat was so dreye
Out of a wang toþe þ̉er/re sprang anoıı̄un a well
Of which he drank ynough shorti to seye
Þus helpt him god as Iudicu can telle
By veray force at Gasou on a nyght
Maugre philistience of that Cite
The gatis of þe toun he haþ up plight
⁊and on his bakke ycaried hem haþ he
High on an hille wher̉er/re as men might se
O . noble ⁊and mighti Sampson leef ⁊and dere
Ne haddistow told to woman thi secree
In al þis world ne had ben thi pere
This Sampsoıı̄un neiþ̉er/re sidre drank ne wine
Ne on his hede cam rasour̉er/re none ne shere
Bi precept of þe messanger diuine
For al his strength þo was in his here
And fulli twenty yere by yere
He hadde of Israel the gouernaunce
But sone aftir̉er/re shal he wepe mani a ter̉er/re
For woman shal bring him to mischaunce
Vnto his lemman Dalida he told
Þat in his heris al his strength lay
⁊and falsli to his fomen she him sold
For sleping in hir barme upon a day
She made to clippe ⁊and shere his her̉er/re away
⁊and made his fomen al his craft aspien
⁊and when thei him founde in such aray
Þei bounde him fast ⁊and put out his iyen
But or his here were clippid or y shave
Þer̉er/re was no bond þᵗat him might bynde
But now is he in prison put in a cave
Wher̉er/re as þei made him at a quern grinde
O . noble Sampsoıı̄un strengist of mankinde
O . whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse
Now maistow wepe wᵗith þine iyen blinde
Siþ þou art falle into wrechidnesse
The ende of þees caytives I. shal you seye
His fomen made a feste vpon a Day
⁊and made him as þeir̉er/re fole aforn hem pley
⁊and this was in a temple of gret aray
But at last he made a foule affray
For he two postis shoke ⁊and made hem fall
⁊and doun felle temple ⁊and all þer̉er/re it lay
⁊and slue himselue ⁊and eke his fomen alle .
This is the ende of princes eủer/reychon
⁊and eke a þousand bodies wer̉er/re y slain
Wᵗith falling of þe gret temple of stone
Of sampsoıı̄un wil I no more seyne
But war̉er/re of þis ensample olde ⁊and pleyn
Þat no men tel her̉er/re counceil to her wivis
Of such þing as þei wold haue secret feyn
If þat it touche her lymmes or her lyues /
Of Ercules þat souerein Conquerour̉er/re
Signed his werkis and high renoıı̄un
For in his time of strength he bar̉er/re þe flour̉er/re
He slue ⁊and beraft the skynne fro the leou
He of Centaurus leid the bost adoun
He arpies slough þe cruel . bird felle
He golden appuls beraft the Dragou
He drue out Cerberus þe hounde of hell
He slue the cruel tirrant Buserous
⁊and made his hors to frete him flessh ⁊and bone
He slue þe veray ʆser/sirpent venemous
Of Adeldis two hornes brak he one
And he slue Cacus in a cave of stone
He slue þe geant Antius the strong
He slue the grisli bore ⁊and þat anone
And bare his hede vpon his nekke long
Was neủer/re wight sith the world beganne
Þat slue somani monstres as didde he
Þorout þis wide world his name ran
What for his strength ⁊and for his bounte
⁊and into eueri Ream went he forto se
He was so strong þat noman might hīm let
⁊and at worldis ende as seith . Trophee
In stede of boundis he a piler̉er/re sette
A leman hadde this noble Champiou
Þat hight Diganer̉er/re as fressh as may
⁊and as the clerkis maden menciou
She haþ him sent a shert fressh ⁊and gay
Alas alas this shert and welaway
Envenemed was subtili with alle
Þat or he had werid it half a day
It made his bones from his flessh to fall
But natheles sum clerkis hir excusen
Bi one þat hight Nessus þᵗat it makid
Be as it mai I nyl hir not accusen
But þat his flessh was of þe venēm blakid
When þat þis venem had him þus awakid
And þat he sye none othir̉er/re Remedye
In hote coles he haþ himselue rakid
For wᵗith no venem deyned him to dye
Thus starve þis worthi mighti Ercules
Lo who mai trust of fortune eny þrow
For him þat folowid al þis world of prees
Or he be war̉er/re is y leid fulle lowe
Ful wise is he þat himselue can know
Bewar̉er/re for when þat fortune list to glose
Þen waitiþ she hir man doun to throw
By such awey as he wold lest suppose
The mighti trone and þe pcious tresour̉er/re
The glorious Ceptre ⁊and roial maiestee
That hadde the king Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnneth man discriued be
He twyes wanne ierusalem the cite
T Þe vessels of þe temple wᵗith him he lad
At Babilou was his souerein See
In which his glorie ⁊and his delite he had
The feirest childirn of the blood Roiall
Of ierlm he didde do geld anoıı̄un
⁊and made eche of hem to be his þrall
Among al oþir̉er/re Daniel was one
Þat was þe wisist childe of eủer/reychou
For he þe dremes of þe king expound
Wher̉er/re as in Caldy clerk was þer̉er/re none
Þat wist to what fine his dremes sound
This proude king lete make a statur̉er/re of gold
Þre score cubitꝭes long ⁊and vij. in brede
To which ymage boþe yong and olde
Comaundid he to lout ⁊and haue in drede
Or in a furneis ful of flames rede
He shuld be brent þat wold not obey
But neủer/re wold assent to that Dede
Daniel / ne his yong felows twey
This king was proude passing his degree
He wend god that sitte in maiestee
Had not ben so gret a lord as he
Bu sodeinli he lost his Dignite
⁊and like a best him semed forto be
⁊and ete hay as an oxe ⁊and lay þer̉er/re out
In reyne wᵗith wilde bestis walkid he
Til certeyn tyme was comen about
And like an Egles fethirs was his heris
His nailes like birdis clawis were
God releued him at certein yeris
⁊and yaue him wit ⁊and þen wᵗith mani a teer̉er/re
He þankid god / ⁊and euer his lif in fere
Was he to do amysse or more trespace
⁊and or þat time he leid was on his beer̉er/re
He knew þat god was ful of might ⁊and gᵃce
His sonne which that hight Balthezar̉er/re
Þat held þe Ream aftir his fadirs day
He bi his fadir coude not bewar̉er/re
For proude he was of hert ⁊and of aray
⁊and eke an ydoloster was he ay
His high astate assured him no þing
But fortune cast him / doun he lay
⁊and sodeinli his Ream gan diuide
A fest he made vnto his lordis alle
Vpon a time he made hem bliþe be
⁊and þan his officers gan he to call
Go bring furth the vessels coþ he
Which þat my fadir in his ꝓprosꝑper/parite
Out of the temple of ierlm beraft
⁊and to oure high goddis thank we
Of honour̉er/re þat oure elders wᵗith us laft
His wif his lordis ⁊and his concubynes
Ay drunken whils þeir appetit last
Out of þees noble vessels sundri wines
⁊and on a walle he his iyen cast
⁊and saw an hand armles þᵗat wrote fast
For fere of which he quoke ⁊and sighid sore
Þis hand þat Balthazar made so sore agast
Wrote mane techil phares ⁊and no more
In alle that lond Magicien was þ̉er/re none
Þat couþe expoun what þis lrēm ment
But Daniel expound it anone
And seid king . god to thi fadir sent
Glorie ⁊and honour / Reigne and rent
⁊and he was proude ⁊and no þing god ne drad
⁊and þerfore god gret wreche upon him sent
⁊and him beraft the regne that he had
He was out cast of mannes cumpani
With assis was his habitacioıı̄un
⁊and ete hey as a best in wete ⁊and drye
Til þat he knew bi grace ⁊and bi resoıı̄un
Þat god of heuen hath dominacioıı̄un
On eueri Ream and euery creature
⁊and then had he of him Compassioıı̄un
⁊and him restored his ream in his figure
Eke thou art his sonne and proude also
And knowist al thees thingis pⁱriuely
And rebellist to god ⁊and art his foo
Þou drankist eke of his vessels boldili
Thi wif eke ⁊and thi wenchis sinfulli
Drank of þe vessels sundrie wines
And heried fals goddis cursidli
Þerfore to þee shape gret pine is
This hand was sent fro god þᵗat on þe wall
Wrote mane techil phares trust to me
Thi reigne is do þou weldist it not at all
Diuidid is thi ream and it shal be
To Medes and to perces yeuen coþ he
⁊and thilk same night þe king was slaw
And Darius occupieth his Degre
Þough he þerto had neyþer right ne law
Lordingꝭes hereby mai ye ensamples take
Hough þat in lordship is no sicurnes
For when fortune wil a man forsake
He berith awey his regne and his riches
And eke his frendis both more ⁊and lesse
And when a man haþ frendis þurȝ fortune
Mishappe wil make him enmyes I gesse
This ꝓprouerbe is ful true ⁊and ful comune

⁊and to his doughtir̉er/re þat stode him beside
Which he knew in high sentence habound
He bad hir tell what it signified
And she his dreme gan þus to expounde
The tree qˢ she the galhous is to mene
And Iubiter betokneþ snowe ⁊and reyne
And phebus wᵗith his towail so clene
Þo ben þe sonne stremes forto seyne
Þou shat enhangid be fadir certeyne
Reyne shal þe wassh ⁊and son shal þe drye
Þus warned she him ful plat ⁊and pleyn
His doughter þat callid was phavy
Enhangid was Cresus the proud kyng
His roial trone might him not availe
Tragedis is none oþir maner thing
Ne can in syneyng crye ne bewaile
But þat fortune alway wil assaile
Wᵗith vnwar̉er/re stroke þe Reames þᵗat ben proude
For when men trust hir þen wil she fail
And couer hir bright face wᵗith a cloude

l.hi: The ꝓprolog of þe Nonnes prest

div.l: HO ꝙquod þe knight good ʆser/sir no more of þis
Þat ye haue seid is right ynow y wis
And moch more / for litle heuynesse
Is right ynough to moch folk as I gesse
I sey for me it is a grete disese
Wher̉er/re as men haue ben in gret welþ ⁊and ese
To here of þeir sodein falle alas
⁊and when þei haue ben in gret astate
⁊and clymben up ⁊and wexen fortunate
And ther̉er/re abiden in prosperite
Such þing is gladsum as þinkis me
⁊and such thing were goodli forto tell
Ye ꝙquod oure hoost be seint poulis bell
Ye sey right sore þis monk clappᵗ loude
He spak hou fortune coủer/reed wᵗith a cloude
I note neuer̉er/re what ⁊and also of a tragedy
Right now ye herd / ⁊and ꝑper/parde ne remedye
Is it forto bewayl ne to compleyne
That that is done ⁊and als it is a peyne
As ye haue seid to here of heuynesse
Sir monk no more of þˢ so god you bles
Your̉er/re tale anoyeth al þis cumpany
Such talking is not worþ a butt̉er/reflye
For þ̉er/rein is no disport ne game
Wherfore ʆser/sir monk dan pers bi yoᵘur name
I pray you hertili tel vs sumwhat ellis
For truli nere clinking of your̉er/re bellis
Þat on your bridle hongin on eueri side
Bi heuen king þat for vs al dyde
I shuld haue falle doun for slepe
Al þough þe slough had be neuer so depe
Then had your tale be told in veyne
For certeinli as thes clerkis seyne
Wher̉er/re as a man haue may none audiēms
Nought helpeþ to telle his sentence
⁊and wel I wote þe substaunce is in me
If eny þing shal wele reportid be
Sir sey sumwhat of hunting I you prey
Nay ꝙquod þe monk I haue no lust to pley
Now lat anoþir tell as I haue told
Þen spak oure host wᵗith rude spech ⁊and bold
⁊and seid vnto þe nonnest prest anou
Come nere sir prest come hidir ʆser/sir Ion
Tel vs such þing as mai our̉er/re hertꝭes glade
Be mery þough þou ride vpon a Iade
⁊and þough þat he be foul ⁊and ful lene
If he wil ʆser/sirue þee rek þee not a been
Loke þat þine hert be mery euermoo
Yis host ꝙquod he so mot I ride or goo
But I be meri I wil be blamed
⁊and right anoıı̄un he haþ his tale attamed
⁊and þus he seid to vs euerichone
Þis swete prest þis good man ʆser/sir Ion
The tale of þe Nonnes pste of Chaıı̄untcler̉er/re ⁊and ꝑper/partlot
A pore widow sumdel stept in age
Was whilom duelling in a narow cotage
Besides a grove stonding in a dale
This widow of which I tel you my tale
Siþen þat dai þat she was last a wif
In pacience lad a ful simple lif
For litil was hir catel ⁊and hir rent
But bi husbondri such as god hir sent
She fond hirselue ⁊and eke hir douȝtirn two
Tre large swine she hadde ⁊and no moo
Thre kyne and eke a shepe þᵗat hiȝt mall
Ful soti was hir boure ⁊and eke hir hall
In which she ete mani a sclendre mele
Of poinant sauce hir nedid neủer/re adele
No deinte morcel passid hir throte
Hir diete was accordant to hir cote
Repleciou ne made hir neuer seke
Attempre diete was al hir phisik
Wᵗith litil she toke hir sufficiaunce
Þe gout lette hir noþing forto daunce
Nor poplexie ne shent not hir hede
No wine drank she neiþ̉er/re white ne rede
Hir boord was ʆser/sirued most wᵗith blak ⁊and blak
Milk ⁊and broun brede in which she fond no lak
Seind bacoıı̄un ⁊and sumtime an egge or twey
For she was / as it wer̉er/re in maner̉er/re of a deye
A garden had she enclosid al about
With Stickis and a drye diche about
In which she had a cok þᵗat hight . chauntcler
In al þe lond of crowing nas his peer
His voice was merier̉er/re þen þe meri orgou
On masse daies þat in the church goıı̄un
Wel sicurer̉er/re was þe crowing in his logge
Þen is a clok or an abbeyes Orlage
Bi nature he knew eche ascenciou
Of equinoxiall of that Towne
For when .xv. grees wer̉er/re descendid
Þan knew he it might not be amendid
His combe was redder̉er/re þen þe fine corall
And embatayld as it wer̉er/re a Castel wall
Like azure were his leggis and his tone
His bllle bille was blak as þe Iete stone
His nailes whitt̉er/re then þe lili floure
⁊and like burnissht gold was his colour
This gentil cok had in his goủer/renaunce
Seven hennes forto do him plesaunce
Which were his sustirs ⁊and his ꝑper/paramoᵘurs
⁊and wondir like to him as of colours
Of which þe feirist hued vnd þrote
Was clepid feir̉er/re damesel pertelote
Curteis she was discret ⁊and deboneyr
⁊and cumpainable ⁊and bare hirselue so feir̉er/re
Siþens þat day þat she was vij . night old
That truli she haþ þe hert in hold
Of chauntcler̉er/re loken in euery litth
He loued hir so þat wel was him þ̉er/rewᵗith
But such a ioy it was to her̉er/re him sing
When þat þe bright son began to spⁱring
In swete accord my lefe is fare on lond
For þat time as I haue vndirstond
Bestis and birdis coude speke ⁊and sing
And so befel that in the dawnyng
As Chauntcler̉er/re among his wivis alle
Sate on his perche þat was in the halle
And next him sate this feire ꝑper/partelote
This chauntcler̉er/re gan grone in his þrote
As man þat in his dreme is drechid sore
And when ꝑper/partelot thus herd him rore
She was agast / and seid hert dere
What eiled you to grone in þis manere
Ye ben a very sleper̉er/re fy for shame
And he answerd ⁊and seid thus madame
I prey you þat ye take it not a grefe
By god me mette þat I was in such mischef
That yit myne hert is sore affright
Now god coþ he my sweuen he rede aright
And kepe my body out of foule prysou
Me dremed that I romed vp and doun
Wᵗithyn oure yerd wher̉er/re as I saw a best
Was like an hounde ⁊and wold haue made arrest
Vpou my bodi ⁊and wold haue had me dede
His colour̉er/re was betwix white ⁊and rede
⁊and tipped was his tail / ⁊and boþe his eris
Wᵗith blak vnlike þe remenᵃnt of his heris
His snoute small wᵗith glowing iyen twey
Yit for his loke for fere almost I deye
This causid me my groning doutlesse
Avoy qd she fy on you hertlesse
Alas qd she for bi þat god aboue
Now haue ye lost myne hert ⁊and al my loue
I can not loue a coward be my feith
For certꝭes what so eny woman seith
We al desiren þat if it might so be
To haue husbondis hardi wise ⁊and fre
⁊and secret ⁊and no negard ne no fole
Ne him þat is agast of euery tole
Ne none avauntour̉er/re bi þᵗat god aboue
Hou durst ye sey for shame vnto yoᵘur loue
Þat eny þing might make you afferd
Haue ye no mannes hert ⁊and haue a berd
Alas ⁊and can ye be agast of swevens
Sweuens engendren of replecions
When humours ben to habundant in a wight
Certꝭes þe dreme which ye han had to night
Comeþ of the grete Superfluite
Of your high rede colre sir parde
Which causiþ folk to dreme her dremes
Of arrowes ⁊and of fires wᵗith rede lemes
Of rede bestis that wille hem bite
Of contec ⁊and of whelpis gret ⁊and lite
Right as þe humour̉er/re of malencoly
Causiþ mani men in slepe to crye
For fere of bestis and boles blake
Or ellis blake deuels wil hem take
Of oþir humours coude I telle also
Þat maken many men in slepe ful wo
But I wil passe as lightly as I can
Lo Caton that was so wise a man
Seid he not þus / ne do no fors of dremes
Now ʆser/sir ꝙquod she when we fle fro þᵉ bemes
For goddis loue as takiþ sum laxatif
Vp perel of my soule ⁊and of my life
I counceil you þe best I wil not lye
But boþe of colre and malencoly
Ye purge you / ⁊and for ye shul not tary
Þough þat in þis toun is none apoticary
I shal myselue two herbis teche you
Þat shal be your̉er/re helpe ⁊and your̉er/re prowe
⁊and in þe garden two herbis shal I finde
Which han of ꝓpropirte bi kynde
To purge you beneþe ⁊and eke aboue
Forgetiþ not þis for goddis ovn loue
Ye ben ful colrik of your̉er/re complexiou
Bewar̉er/re þat þe sonne in his ascenciou
Ne finde you replete of your̉er/re humoᵘurs hote
⁊and if it do I dare wele leyn a grote
Þat ye shul haue a feuer̉er/re tercian
Or an ague þat may be your̉er/re bane
A day or two ye shul haue digestives
Of wormes / or ye take your laxatiues
Of lauriol Centaury and fumytere
Or ellis of elbere þat growith ther̉er/re
Of catapuce or of gaytis beryes
Of herbe Ive growing in oure yerd þ̉er/re mery is
Pike hem vpright as þey grow ⁊and ete hem yn
Be mery husbond by your̉er/re fadir kynne
Drediþ no dreme I can sey you no mor̉er/re
Madame qd he gramercy of youre lore
But naþeles as touching daun Catou
Þat hath of wisdom such grete Renoun
By god men may in olde bokes rede
One of the gretist auctour out of drede
Of many a man more auctorite
Then euer Catoıı̄un was so mot I thee
Þat alle the reủer/rese seyn of thys sentence
And haue wel founden bi experience
Þat dremes ben significacioıı̄uns
As wel of ioye as of tribulacōmns
Þat folk endure in this lif present
Þer̉er/re nediþ not to make of þis noıı̄un argumēmt
The veray prefe shewiþ it in dede
As one of þe gretist auctour̉er/re out of drede
Seiþ þus / þat whilom two felows wēmt
On pilgremage . in ful good intent
⁊and happid so þei com into a toun
Wher̉er/re as þer̉er/re was such congregacōmn
Of peple . ⁊and of streit herburgage
Þat thei found not so moch as a cotage
In which thei boþe might ylogid be
Wherfore þey must of necessite
As for þat nyght depart of cıı̄unpany
⁊and eche of hem goþ into his hostry
⁊and toke his loging as it wold fall
Þat one of hem was logid in a stall
Ferre in a yerd wᵗith oxen of þe plough
Þat oþir man was logid wel ynough
As was his auenture ⁊and his fortune
Þat vs goủer/reneþ alle as in comune
And so bifel long or it wer̉er/re day
Þat one mette in his bedde þer he lay
Hou þat his felow gan on him calle
⁊and seid alas for in an oxe stalle
Þis night shal I . be morþird þ̉er/re I lye
Now helpe me dere broþir̉er/re or I dye
In al hast come to me he seid
This man out of his slepe for fer̉er/re abreid
But when þat he was wakend out of slepe
He turned him ⁊and toke of þis no kepe
Him þought his dreme was not but vanite
Þus twice in his slepe dremed he
⁊and at þird time yit his felowe
Come as him þought lo I am slawe
Behold my blody woundis depe ⁊and wyde
Aryse vp erly in the morow tyde
And at the west gate of the town qˢ he
A cartful of dunge ther̉er/re shaltow see
In which my body is hidde ful pryuely
Do thilk Cart arresten boldily
Mi gold causid my mordre soth to seyn
⁊and told him euery point hou he was sleyn
Wᵗith a ful pitous face . pale of hue
⁊and trustiþ wel his dreme he founde ful true
For on þe morne as sone as it was day
To his felowis ynne he toke the weye
⁊and when he come vnto this oxes stalle
Aftir his felowe he gan to calle
The hostiller̉er/re answerd him anone
⁊and seid sir̉er/re youre felowe is y gone
As sone as day he went out of þe town
This man gan falle in gret suspeciou
Remembring on his dremes þᵗat he mette
⁊and furþ he goth no lenger wold he lette
Vnto þe westgate of þe toun and fond
A dung cart as he went to dunge lond
Þat was ycaried in the same wise
As ye haue herd þe dede man deuise
⁊and wᵗith an hardi hert he gan to crye
Vengeance ⁊and Iustice of this felonye
My felow morþird is þis same night
⁊and in þis cart here liþe gaping vpright
The dedes man þat morþird was all new
O blisful god þat art so iust and true
Lo hou þou bewreyest morþir alway
Morþir wil out þat se we dai bi day
Morþir̉er/re is so wraþsum ⁊and abhominable
To god þat is so iust and resonable
Þat he ne wold not suffre it hidde be
Þough it abide a yere or two or þre
Morþir̉er/re wil out þis is my conclusioıı̄un
⁊and right anoıı̄un ministres of the toun
Haue hent þe carter̉er/re ⁊and sore him peined
And eke þe hostiller̉er/re so sore constreined
Þat þey confesse þeir̉er/re wikydnesse anone
And were y hangid by the nekke bone
¶ Here may men se þat dremes ben to drede
And certꝭes in the same boke I rede
Right in the next chapit̉er/re I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blisse
Two men þat wold haue passid þᵉ see
For certein cause into ferre cuntree
If þat the winde ne had ben contrary
Þat made hem in a cite forto tary
Þat stode ful mery vpon an haven side
But on a day ayens the even tide
Þe winde gan chaunge ⁊and blue as hīm lest
Ioli and glad thei went vnto rest
And cast hem ful erli forto sayle
But herken hou one man fil in gret ꝑper/pareil
That one of hem in sleping as he lay
Him mette a wondre dreme ayens day
Him þought a man stode bi his side
⁊and him comaundid þat he shuld abide
⁊and seid him þus / if þou to morou wend
Þou shat be drowned my tale is at an end
He woke ⁊and told his felow what he mette
⁊and preyd him his viage forto lette
As for þat day he prayd him forto byde
His felow that lay be his bedde side
Gan forto laugh ⁊and scorned him ful fast
No dreme ꝙquod he may myne hert agast
Þat I wil lette forto do myn thinges
I sette not a myte bi dreminges
For dremes ben vanitees and iapes
Men dremen alday of oules ⁊and of apes
⁊and of mani a maze therwithall
Men dreme of þingꝭes þᵗat neủer/re was ne shal
But siþ I se þat þou wilt here abide
⁊and þus forslouth wilfulli thi tide
God wote it rueþ me ⁊and haue gode day
⁊and þus he toke his leue ⁊and went his way
And or þat he had half his cours yseyled
I note whi ne what mischaunce it eyled
But casually þe shippis boþom to rent
And shippe ⁊and man vndir the watir went
In sight of othir shippis him beside
Þat wᵗith him sailid þe same tide
⁊and therfore he seid ꝑper/partelot so dere
Bi such ensamples olde must þou ler̉er/re
Þat mani a dreme ful sore is to drede
Lo in þe lif of seint kenelme I rede
Þat was kenulphis son þe noble king
Of Metenrike / hou kenelme met a þing
A litle or he was morþird on a day
His morþir in his avisioıı̄un he say
His norice him expound euerydel
His dreme / ⁊and bad him forto kepe hīm wel
From treson / but he was but vij yer̉er/re old
And þerfore litle tale hath he told
Of eny dreme / so holi was his hert
Be god I had leuer then my Shert
Þat ye had herd his legende as haue I
Dame ꝑper/partelot I sey you truly
Macrobeus that write þavisioıı̄un
In Aufric of þe worþi Ciprioıı̄un
Affermeþ dremes ⁊and seiþ þᵗat þei ben
Warning of þingꝭes þᵗat men aft̉er/re sene
And furþ̉er/remore I pray you lokeþ wel
The olde testament of Daniell
If he held dremes of eny vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph ⁊and ye shull se
Whedir dremes be sumtime I sei not all
Warning of þingꝭes þat shal aft̉er/re fall
Loke eke of Egipt the king pharao
His baker and his botiller also
Wher̉er/re þei ne felt effect in dremes
Whoso wil seche þe acte of sundri Remes
May rede of dremes mani a wond þing
Lo Cresus which þat was of lide king
Met he not þat he sate vpon a tree
Which signified þat he shuld an hangid be
Lo hereþ Adromaca Ectors wife
Þat day þat Ector shuld lete his lif
She dremed on þe same nyght toforn
Hou that the lif of Ector shuld be lorn
If þat day he went into bataile
She warned him but it miȝt not avail
He went forto fight neủer/re þe lesse
And þer̉er/re he was slain of Achilles
But þat tale is alto long to telle
And eke it is nye dai I mai not duell
Shortli I seye as for a conclusiou
That I shal haue of this avisiou
Aduersite / and I sei furthirmore
Þat I ne tell of laxatives no store
For þei ben venemous I wote riȝt wel
I hem defie I loue hem neuer̉er/re adel
Now lat vs speke of mirþe ⁊and leve al þˢ
Madame pertlot so haue I ioy or blis
Of one þing god haþ sent me large gᵃce
For when I se þe beaute of your̉er/re face
Ye ben so scarlet rede about your̉er/re iyen
It makis al my drede forto dyen
For al as sicur̉er/re as in principio
Mulier est hominis confucio
Madame þe sentence of þˢ latine is
Woman is mannes ioy ⁊and mannes blis
For when I fele on night yoᵘur soft side
Al be it þat I mai not on you ride
For þat oure perch is made so narow alas
I am so fulle of ioye and of solace
Þat I defie both sweuen ⁊and dreme
⁊and wᵗith that word he fligh doun fro þᵉ beme
For it was dai / ⁊and eke his hennes alle
⁊and wᵗith a chukke he gan hem forto call
For he had found a corn lay in þe yerd
Rial he was he was no more afferd
He fethird pertlot twenty tyme
And trode as oft or it was fulli pⁱrime
He loked as it were a grym leon
⁊and on his toes he romed vp ⁊and doun
Him deyned not to sett / his fete on groıı̄und
Ay chukkid he when he a corn had founde
And to him then ranne his wives alle
Thus roial as a prince in his halle
Leve I þis chauntclere in his pasture
⁊and . aftir̉er/re wil I telle of his auenture
Whan þe moneþ in which þe world begām
Þat hight march / when god first made man
Were complete / and passed were also
Siþ march began þirti daies and mo
Bifel that chauntcler̉er/re in his pride
His seuen wivis walking bi his side
Cast vp his iyen to þe bright sonne
Þat in þe signe of taurus was y ronne
Thirty degrees ⁊and one ⁊and sumwhat more
He knew be kinde ⁊and bi none othir̉er/re lore
Þat it was prime he knew wᵗith blisful steven
He sonne he sye was clumben vpon þᵉ heuēm
Fourti degrees ⁊and one and more y wis
Madame ꝑper/partlot my worldli blis
Herken hou þees blisful birdis sing
And se þe fressh floures hou þei spring
Ful is myne hert of reuel ⁊and of solace
But sodeinli him felle a sorouful case
For euer þe latter ende of ioye is sone agoo
⁊and comonli oft time it fallith so
And if Arthour̉er/re coude feire endyte
He in crounyng might saufly write
As for a souereyne notabilite
Now euery wise man herkne to me
This story is as true I vndirtake
As is the book of launcelot de lake
That women held in gret reuerence
Now wil I turn ayen to my sentence
A . colefox ful of sleight and iniquite
That in þe grove had woned yeris þre
By high ymaginacōmn aforne cast
Þe same night þurgh þe heggꝭes he brast
Into þe yerd wher̉er/re Chauntcler̉er/re þe feyr̉er/re
Was wont with his wivis to repeire
And in a bedde of wortis stille he lay
Til it was past vndirn of þe day
Waiting his time on chauntcler to fall
As gladli done thees homicides all
Þat in await lyen to mordre men
O . fals morþerer̉er/re rouking in þi denne
O . new Scarioth ⁊and new Geniloıı̄un
Fals dissimilour̉er/re . O . greke Simoıı̄un
Þat brought troy al vtt̉er/rely to sorow
O . chauntcler̉er/re acursid be þat morow
Þat þou into þe yerd fligh fro þe bemes
Þou were ful wel y warned be þi dremes
Þat ilke day was perilous vnto thee
But þat god aforn wote mot nedis be
Aftir þoppinioıı̄un of certein clerkis
Witnesse on him þat eny clerk is
That in scole is grete altercaciou
In þis mater̉er/re and gret disputacoıı̄un
⁊and hath ben of an hundird þousand men
But I ne can not bult it to the brenne
As can þe holy doctour̉er/re Augustine
Or Boice or þe busshop Bradwardine
Wheþir̉er/re þat goddis wil aforn witing

That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of

Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym

(base) Now certes a man to pride him in the godes of grace is eke an
outrageous folye

(base) for thilk yiftes of grace that shold haue turned hym to
godenesse and to medicyne turneth hym to venym and to confusiou As
seith Seint Gregorie

(base) Certes also who that prydeth hym in the
goodes of fortune he is a ful gret fool for som tyme is a
man a gret lord by the morwe that is a kaytif and a wrecche er
it be nyght

(base) and som tyme the richesse of a man is cause of
his deeth som tyme the delices of a man ben cause of the
greuous maladie thurgh which he dyeth

(base) Certes the commendacioun of the peple is som tyme ful fals and ful brotil for
to triste this day they preise to morwe they blame

(base) god
woot desir to haue the commendacioun eek of peple hath caused deth to many a bisy man

(base) Now certes a man to pride
hym in the goodes of grace is eek an outrageous folye for
thilke yiftes of grace that sholde haue turned hym to goodnesse
and to medicine turneth hym to venym and to confusioun as seyth
Seint Gregorie

(base) Now sith that ye han vndirstonde what is pride and

(base) Remediun contra pcciun superbie

sourdeth and spryngeth
(base) ¶ Remedium contra peccatum Superbie

(base) Now shul ye vnderstonde which is
the remedie agayns pride and that is humylitee or mekenesse

(base) that is a vertu thurgh which a man hath verray kNoweleche of hym self and holdeth of hym self no pris ne deyntee
as in regard of hise desertes considerynge euere his freletee

(base) Now ben ther iij maneres of humylitee As humylitee in

(base) The humylitee in herte is in iiij maneres that oon

god of heuene Another is whan he ne despiseth noon other

(base) the thridde is whan he ne rekketh nat thogh men holde

And whan he bikNoweth with his owene Mouth that he is

thyng ther of amenuseth

(base) humylitee eek in werk is in iiij
maneres the firste is whan he putteth othere men biforn
hym the seconde is to chese the loweste place ouer al
The thridde is gladly to assente

(base) alle manere
of frendshipe Thanne comth scornynge of his neighebore
al do he neuer so wel

(base) Thanne comth accusynge as whan
man seketh occasioun to anoyen his neighebore which that is lyk
the craft of the deuel that wayteth bothe nyght and day to accusen vs alle

(base) Thanne comth Malignitee thurgh which a man
anoyeth his neighebore pryuely if he may

(base) and if he nat ne
may algate his wikked wil ne shal nat wante as for to
brennen his hous pryuely or enpoysone or sleen hise bestes
and semblable thynges
(base) Remediun contra pcciun Inuidie

(base) Now wol I speken of the remedye agayns this foule synne of Enuye First is the loue
of god principal and louynge of hym self and of his neighebore for soothly that oon ne may nat ben with outhen that
oother

(base) and truste wel that in the name of thy neighebore thow
shalt vnderstonde the name of thy brother for certes alle we
haue o fader flesshly and o moder that is to seyn Adam and
Eue and eek o fader Spirituel that is god of heuene

(base) thy
neighebore artow holden for to loue and wilne hym alle goodnesse and therfore seith god loue thy neighebore as thy self
that is to seyn to sauacion bothe of lyf and soule

(base) and moore
ouer thow shalt loue hym in word and benygne amonestynge
and chastisynge and conforte hym in hise anoyes and preye for hym
with al thyn herte

(base) And in dede thow shalt loue hym in swich
wise that thow shalt doon to hym in charitee as thow woldest
that were doon to thyn owene persone

(base) and therfore thow ne shalt
doon hym no damage in wikked word ne harm in his body
ne in his catel ne in his soule by entisynge of wikked ensample

(base) Thow shalt nat eek desiren his wyf ne none of hyse
thynges Vnderstoond eek that in the name of neighebore is
comprehended his enemy

(base) certes man shal loue his enemy for the
comandement of god and soothly thy freend shaltow loue
in god

(base) I seye thyn enemy shaltow loue for goddes sake by
his comandement for if it were resoun that man sholde hate
his enemy for sothe god nolde nat receyuen vs to his loue
that ben hise enemys

(base) Agayns iij manere of wronges that
his enemy dooth to hym he shal doon iij thynges as thus

(base) Agayns hate and rancour of herte he shal loue hym in herte
Agayns chidynge and wikked wordes he shal preye for his enemy Agayns the wikked dede of his enemy he shal doon
hym bountee

(base) for crist seith loueth youre enemys and preieth
for hem that speke yow harm and eek for hem that yow chacen
and pursuen and dooth bountee to hem that yow haten lo
thus comandeth vs oure lord Ihesu crist to do to oure enemys

(base) for soothly nature dryueth vs to louen oure frendes and parfey
oure enemys
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. han moore nede to loue than oure frendes and
they that moore nede haue certes to hem shal men doon goodnesse

(base) and certes in thilke dede haue we remembraunce of the loue
of Ihesu crist that deyde for hise enemys

(base) and in as muche as
thilke loue is the moore greuous to perfourne so muche is the
moore gret the merite and therfore the louynge of of oure
enemy hath confounded the venym of the deuel

(base) for right
as the deuel is desconfited by humylitee right so is he wownded to the deth by the loue of oure enemy

(base) certes thanne is
loue the medicyne that chaceth out the venym of enuye fro
mannes herte
(base) ¶ Sequitur de Ira
(base) The speces of this pas shullen ben moore largely declared in hire chapitres folwynge
(base) Ira

(base) After Enuye wol I discryuen the synne of Ire for
soothly who so that hath enuye vp on his neighebore
anon he wole communely fynde hym matere of wrathathe in word or in
dede agayns hym to whom he hath enuye

(base) and as wel comth Ire of pride
as of enuye for soothly he that is proud or enuyous is lightly wroth

(base) This synne of Ire after the discryuyng of Seint Augustyn is
wikked wil to ben auenged by word or by dede

(base) Ire after the
philosophre is the feruent blood of man yquyked in his herte
thurgh which he wole harm to hym that he hateth

(base) for certes the
herte of man by eschawfynge and moeuynge of his blood wexeth
so trouble that he is out of alle Iugement of resoun

(base) But ye shal
vnderstonde that Ire is in two maneres that oon of hem is good and
that oother is wikke

(base) the goode Ire is by Ialowsie of goodnesse
thurgh which a man is wrooth with wikkednesse and agayns wikkednesse and therfore seith a wys that Ire is bet than pley

(base) this Ire
is with debonairetee and it is wroth with oute bitternesse nat wroth
agayns the man but wroth with the mysdede of the man as seith
the prophete Dauid Irascimini et nolite peccare

(base) Now vnderstondeth that wikked Ire is in ijmaneres that is to seyn sodeyn Ire
or hastif Ire with oute auysement and consentynge of his reson

(base) the Menyng and the sens of this is that the reson of a man ne
consente nat to thilke sodeyn Ire and thanne is it venyal

(base) Another Ire is ful wikked that comth of felonye of herte auysed
and cast bifore with wikked wil to do vengeaunce and ther tohis resoun
consenteth and soothly this is dedly synne

(base) this Ire is so displesant to god that it troubleth his hous and chaceth the holy goost
out of mannes soule and wasteth and destroyeth the liknesse of
god that is to seyn the vertu that is in mannes soule

(base) and put in
hym the liknesse of the deuel and bynymeth
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. the man fro god that
is his rightful lord

(base) this Ire is a ful gret plesaunce to the
deuel for it is the deueles forneys that is eschawfed with the
fyr of helle

(base) for certes right so as fyr is moore myghty to
destroye erthely thynges than another Element right so Ire
is myghty to destroye alle spirituel thynges

(base) Looke how that
fyr of smale gleedes that ben almoost dede vnder the Asshen
wolen quyke agayn whan they ben touched with brym ston
right so Ire wole euere mo quyke agayn whan it is touched
by the pryde that is couered in mannes herte

(base) for certes fyr ne may
nat come out of no thyng but if it were first in the same
thyng naturelly as fyr is drawen out of flyntes with
Steel

(base) and right so as pryde is ofte tyme matere of Ire right
so is rancour norice and kepere of Ire

(base) Ther is a manere tree
as seith sein ysidre that
whan men maken fir of thilke tree and couere the coles of it with Asshen
soothly the fir of it wol lasten al a yeer or moore

(base) And right so fareth
it of rancour whan it is ones conceyued in the hertes of som men
certein it wol lasten perauenture from oon Estre day vn to another Estre
day and moore

(base) but certes thilke man is ful fer fro the mercy of god in
thilke while

(base) In this forseyde deueles fourneys ther forgen iij shrewes Pride that ay bloweth and encreesseth the fir by chidynge and wikked
wordes

(base) Thanne stant Enuye and holdeth the hoote Iren vpon the hte
of man with a peire of longe toonges of long rancour

(base) And thanne
stant the synne of contumelie or strif and cheeste and batereth and
forgeth by vileyns repreuynges

(base) Certes this cursed synne anoyeth
bothe to the man hym self and eek to his neighebore For soothly almoost
al the harm that any man dooth to his neighebore comth of wratthe

(base) for certes
outrageous wratthe dooth al that euere the deuel hym comaundeth for he ne
spareth neither crist ne his sweete mooder

(base) And in his outrageous anger and
Ire allas allas ful many oon at that tyme feeleth in his herte ful wikkedly
bothe of crist and of alle hise halwes
(base) but spekyth and sklaundryth his neyghbour

(base) Is nat this a cursed vice yis certes
Allas it bynymeth from man his wit and his resoun and al his debonaire
lif espiritueel that sholde kepen his soule

(base) Certes it bynymeth eek
goddes due lordshipe and that is mannes soule and the loue of hise
neighebores It stryueth eek alday agayn trouthe It reueth hym the quiete of his herte and subuerteth his soule

(base) Of Ire comen thise stynkynge
engendrures First hate that is oold wratthe discord thurgh which a
man forsaketh his olde freend ful longe
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

(base) And thanne cometh werre and
euery manere of wrong that man dooth to his neighebore in body or in catel

(base) Of this cursed synne of Ire cometh eek manslaughtre And vnderstonde
wel that homycide that is manslaughtre is in diuerse wise Som manere
of homycide is spiritueel and som is bodily

(base) Spiritueel manslaughtre
is in vjthynges First by hate as Seint Iohn seith he that hateth his
brother is homycide

(base) Homycide is eek by bakbitynge of whiche bakbiteres seith Salomon that they han two swerdes with whiche the sleen hir
neighebores For soothly as wikke is to bynyme his good name as his lyf

(base) Homycide is eek in yeuynge of wikked conseil by fraude as for to yeuen
conseil to areysen wrongful custumes and taillages

(base) of whiche seith
Salomon Leou rorynge and Bere hongry been like to the crueel lordshipes in withholdynge or abreggynge of the shepe or the hyre or of the wages of seruauntz or elles in vsures or in withdrawynge of the almesse of
poure folk

(base) For which the wise man seith Fedeth hym that almoost dyeth
for honger for soothly but if thow feede hym thou sleest hym and alle
thise been deedly synnes

(base) Bodily manslaughtre is whan thow sleest him
with thy tonge In oother manere as whan thou comandest to sleen a
man or elles yeuest hym conseil to sleen a man

(base) Manslaughtre in dede
is in iiij maneres That oon is by lawe right as a Iustice dampneth hym that is coupable to the deeth but lat the Iustice be war that
he do it rightfully and that he do it nat for delit to spille blood but
for kepynge of rightwisnesse

(base) Another homycide is that is doon
for necessitee as whan o man sleeth another in his defendaunt and that
he ne may noon ootherwise escape from his owene deeth

(base) but certeinly
if he may escape with outen manslaughtre of his Aduersarie and sleeth
hym he dooth synne and he shal bere penance as for deedly synne

(base) Eek if a man by caas or auenture shete an Arwe or caste a stoon with
which he sleeth a man he is homycide

(base) Eek if a wonman by necligence ouerlyeth hir child in hir slepyng it is homycide and deedly
synne
(base) and horrible dedly synnes

(base) Eek whan man destourbeth concepcioun of a child and maketh a womman outher bareyne by drynkynge venenouse herbes thurgh
which she may nat conceyue or sleeth a child by drynkes wilfully
or elles putteth certeine material thynges in hir secree places to slee
the child

(base) or elles dooth vnkyndely synne by which man or wonman shedeth hir nature in manere or in place ther as a child may nat be conceiued or elles if a woman haue conceyued and hurt hir child and sleeth
the child yet it is homycide

(base) What seye we eek of wommen that mordren hir children for drede of worldly shame certes
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image. an horrible homicide

(base) Homycide is eek if a man approcheth to a wonman by desir of lecherie thurg
which the child is perissed or elles smyteth a wonman wityngly thurgh
which she leseth hir child Alle thise been homycides and horrible deedly
synnes

(base) Yet comen ther of Ire manye mo synnes as wel in word as
in thoght and in dede as he that arretteth vp on god or blameth god of
thyng of which he is hym self gilty or despiseth god and alle hise halwes as doon thise cursede hasardours in diuerse contrees

(base) This cursed synne doon they whan they feelen in hir hertes ful wikkedly of god and
of hise halwes

(base) Also whan they treten vnreuerently the sacrement of
the Auter thilke synne is so greet that vnnethe may it been releessed
but that the mercy of god passeth alle hise werkes it is so greet and he
so benigne
(base) Thanne comth of Ire attry Angre whan a man is sharply amonested in his shrifte to forleten his synne

(base) thanne wole he be
angry and answeren hokerly and angrily and deffenden or excusen his
synne by vnstedefastnesse of his flessh or elles he dide it for to holde
compaignye with hise felawes or elles he seith the feend enticed hym

(base) or elles he dide it for his youthe or elles his conpleccioun is so corageous that he may nat forbere or elles it is his destinee as he seith vnto a certein age or elles he seith it cometh hym of gentillesse of hise
Auncestres and semblable thynges

(base) Alle this manere of folk so wrappen hem in hir synnes that they ne wol nat deliuere hem self For
soothly no wight that excuseth hym wilfully of his synne may nat
been deliuered of his synne til that he mekely bikNoweth his synne
(base) After this thanne cometh sweryng that is expres agayn the comandement of god and this bifalleth ofte of anger and of Ire

(base) God seith
thow shalt nat take the name of thy lord god in veyn or in ydel Also
oure lord Ihesu crist seith by the word of Seint Mathew

(base) Nolite iura
re omniuo

(base) Ne wol ye nat
swere in alle manere neither by heuene for it is goddes trone ne
by erthe for it is the bench of his feet ne by Ierusalem for it is the
Citee of a greet kyng ne by thyn heed for thou mayst nat make an
heer whit ne blak

(base) but seyeth by youre word ye ye and nay nay
and what that is moore it is of yuel seith crist

(base) For cristes sake
ne swereth nat so synfully

herte bones and body For certes it semeth that ye thynke that the
cursede Iewes ne dismembred nat ynough the preciouse persone of crist
but ye dismembre hym moore

(base) And if so be that the lawe compelle
yow to swere thanne rule yow after the lawe of god in youre sweryng as seith Ieremye 4ᵒ capitulo Thou shalt kepe iij condicions
Thou shalt swere in trouthe in doom and in rightwisnesse

(base) this
is to seyn thou shalt swere sooth for euery lesynge is agayns
Crist For crist is verray trouthe And thynk wel this that euery
greet swerere nat compelled lawefully to swere the wounde
shal nat departe from his hous whil he vseth swich vnleueful sweryng

(base) Thou shalt sweren eek in doom whan thou art
constreyned by thy domesman to witnessen the trouthe

(base) Eek
thow shalt nat swere for enuye ne for fauor ne for meede but for
rightwisnesse and for declaracioun of it to the worship of god and helpyng of thyne euene cristene

(base) And therfore euery man that taketh
goddes name in ydel or falsly swereth with his mouth or elles
taketh on hym the name of crist to be called a cristene man and
lyueth agayns Cristes lyuynge and his techynge alle they taken
goddes name in ydel

(base) Looke eek what seint Peter seith Actuum 4ᵒ
Non est aliud nomen sub celo et cetera Ther nys noon oother name seith seint Peter vnder heuene yeuen to men in which
they mowe be saued that is to seyn but the name of Ihesu crist

(base) Take kepe eek how that the precious name of crist as seith seint
Paul ad Philipenses 2ᵒ In nomine Ihesu et cetera that in the name
of Ihesu euery knee of heuenely creatures or erthely or of helle
sholden bowe for it is so heigh and so worshipful that the cursede feend in helle sholde tremblen to heeren it ynempned

(base) Thanne semeth it that men that sweren so horriblely by his blessed name that they despise hym moore booldely than dide the cursede Iewes or elles the deuel that trembleth whan he heereth his
name

(base) Ow certes sith that sweryng but if it be lawefully doon
is so heighly deffended muche worse is forsweryng falsly and yet
nedelees

(base) What seye we eek of hem that deliten hem in sweryng
and holden it a gentrie or a manly dede to swere grete othes And
what of hem that of verray vsage ne cesse nat to swere grete othes al be the cause nat worth a straw certes it is horrible synne

(base) Swerynge sodeynly with oute auysement is eek a synne
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

(base) But lat vs go Now to thilke horrible sweryng of Adiuracioun
and coniuracioun as doon thise false Enchauntours or Nigromanens in bacyns ful of water or in a bright swerd in a Cercle or
in a fir or in a shulder boon of a sheep

(base) I kan nat seye but that
they doon cursedly and dampnablely agayns crist and al the
feith of hooly chirche

(base) What seye we of hem that bileeuen in diuynailes as by flight or by noyse of briddes or of beestes or by
sort by Geomancie by dremes by chirkynge of dores or crakkynge of houses by gnawynge of rattes and swich manere
wrecchednesse

(base) certes al this thyng is deffended by god and by
al hooly chirche For which they been acursed til they come to
amendement that on swich filthe setten hir bileeue

(base) Charmes for woundes or maladie of men or of beestes if they taken
any effect it be per auenture that god suffreth it for folk sholden
yeue the moore feith and reuerence to his name

(base) Now wol I
speken of lesynges which generally is fals signyficacioun
of word in entente to deceyuen his euene cristene

(base) Som lesynge is of which ther comth noon auantage to no wight And
som lesynge turneth to the ese and profit of o man and to disese and damage of another man

(base) Another lesynge for to sauen his lyf or his catel comth of delit for to lye in which delit
they wol forge a long tale and peynten it with alle circumstaunces where al the ground of the tale is fals

(base) Som lesynge
comth for he wole sustene his word And som lesynge comth of
reccheleesnesse with outen auisement and semblable thynges

(base) Lat
vs Now touche the vice of flaterynge which ne comth nat gladly
but for drede or for coueitise

(base) Flaterye is generally wrongful
preisynge Flatereres been the deueles norices that norissen hise
children with Milk of losengerie

(base) For sothe Salomon seith that
flaterie is wors than detraccioun for som tyme detraccion maketh an hauteyn man be the moore humble for he dredeth detraccion but certes flaterye that maketh a man to enhauncen his herte
and his contenaunce

(base) Flatereres been the deueles Enchauntours
for the make a man to wene of hym self be lyk that he nys nat
lyk

(base) they been lyk to Iudas that bitraysed a man to sellen hym
to hise enemy that is to the deuel

(base) Flatereres

(base) I rekene flarie in the vices of Ire for ofte tyme if o man be wrooth with another thanne
wole he flatere som wight to sustene hym in his querele

(base) Speke we Now of swich cursynge as comth of Irous herte Malisoun
generally may be seyd euery maner power or harm swich cursynge bireueth man fro the regne of god as seith seint Paul

(base) And
ofte tyme swich cursynge wrongfully retorneth agayn to hym that
curseth as a bryd that retorneth agayn to his owene nest

(base) And ouer alle thyng men oghten eschewe to cursen hir children and yeuen to the deuel hir engendrure as ferforth as in hem is certes it
is greet peril and greet synne

(base) Lat vs thanne speken of chidynge
and reproche whiche been ful grete woundes in mannes herte for they
vnsowen the semes of freendshipe in mannes herte

(base) For certes vnnethes may a man pleynly been accorded with hym that hath hym
openly reuyled and repreued in disclaundre This is a ful grisly synne as crist seith in the gospel

(base) And taak kepe Now that he that
repreueth his neighebor outher he repreueth hym by som harm of
peyne that he hath on his body as Mesel croked harlot or by som
synne that he dooth

(base) that he hath ouer his body as mesell Croked
harlot or by som synne that he doth

(base) Now if he repreue hym by harm of peyne
thanne turneth the repreue to Ihesu crist for peyne is sent by the
rightwys sonde of god and by his suffrance be it Meselrie or Maheym
or maladie

(base) And if he repreue hym vncharitably of synne as thou
dronkelewe harlot and so forth thanne aperteneth that to the reioysynge
of the deuel that euere hath ioye that men doon synne
(base) And certes chidynge may nat come but out of a vileyns herte For after the habundance of the herte speketh the mouth ful ofte

(base) And ye shul vnderstonde
that looke by any wey whan any man shal chastise another that he
be war from chidynge and repreuynge For trewely but he be war
he may ful lightly quyken the fir of angre and of wratthe which that
he sholde quenche and perauenture sleeth hym which that he myghte
chastise with benignitee

(base) For as seith Salomon The amyable tonge
is the tree of lyf that is to seyn of lyf espiritueel and soothly a
